Review_Description: Sweetly earthy, floral-toned. Pipe tobacco, jasmine, pink grapefruit zest, pistachio, plum in aroma and cup. Gently tart acidity; crisp, creamy mouthfeel. Richly smoky, sweetly nutty finish.
Coffee Origin: Paranginan, Humbahas Province, Karo Highlands, Sumatra, Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Sweetly earthy, floral-toned. Pipe tobacco, jasmine, pink grapefruit zest, pistachio, plum in aroma and cup. Gently tart acidity; crisp, creamy mouthfeel. Richly smoky, sweetly nutty finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers from trees of the Tim Tim, Catimor and Lasuna varieties of Arabica and processed by the locally traditional washed and wet-hulled method. Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit www.revelcoffee.com or call 406-534-9621 for more information.
Bottom Line: A complex, nutty, floral, sweetly earthy cup: classic Sumatra right down to the distinct pipe tobacco notes.

Review_Description: : Sweetly earth-toned, floral. Vanilla orchid, scorched oak, pipe tobacco, unsweetened cocoa, cashew in aroma and cup. Roasty-sweet with balanced acidity; light, rather fluffy mouthfeel. Earthy, pungent finish with notes of scorched oak and sweet pipe tobacco.
Blind Assessment: : Sweetly earth-toned, floral. Vanilla orchid, scorched oak, pipe tobacco, unsweetened cocoa, cashew in aroma and cup. Roasty-sweet with balanced acidity; light, rather fluffy mouthfeel. Earthy, pungent finish with notes of scorched oak and sweet pipe tobacco.
Notes: Produced at the Simalem Estate in the Karo Regency of North Sumatra from nanolots originating around Lake Toba and processed by the traditional Sumatra washed and wet-hulled method. Vermont Artisan Coffee & Tea provides craft-roasted coffees and quality teas to retail establishments, food service markets, and retail customers throughout New England and beyond. For more information, visit www.vtartisan.com.
Bottom Line: For fans of overtly earthy coffees, this Sumatra, with its sweet pipe tobacco and floral vanilla tones, fits the bill.

Review_Description: Roasty, rich, earthy-sweet. Cocoa powder, tamarind, scorched cedar, cashew brittle, fresh humus in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Gently drying finish with notes of cocoa powder and scorched cedar.
Blind Assessment: Roasty, rich, earthy-sweet. Cocoa powder, tamarind, scorched cedar, cashew brittle, fresh humus in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Gently drying finish with notes of cocoa powder and scorched cedar.
Notes: Peet’s Coffee, now a national chain, was founded by Alfred Peet in 1966, making it one of the first and most influential specialty coffee roasters in the U.S. Visit www.peets.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A dark-roasted twist on the Mocha Java blend from a national chain that is a widely accessible go-to in the U.S. when you’re in the mood for deep, dark familiarity.

Review_Description: Bright, richly aromatic. Bergamot, apricot, lemon verbena, cocoa nib, honey in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with sparkling acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel.The harmonious finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and bergamot.
Coffee Origin: Wenago Woreda, Gedeo Zone, SNNP, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Bright, richly aromatic. Bergamot, apricot, lemon verbena, cocoa nib, honey in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with sparkling acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel.The harmonious finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and bergamot.
Notes: Produced by Hamed Awol, from selections of indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Processed by the washed method, including the addition during the fermentation stage of a special cultured yeast developed specifically for washed-process coffees. Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit www.revelcoffee.com or call 406-534-9621 for more information.
Bottom Line: A bright yeast-processed Ethiopia with a throughline of cocoa nib and citrus notes — rich, juicy, high-toned.

Review_Description: Multi-layered, deep-toned. Dark chocolate, blackberry marjoram, praline, cedar in aroma and cup. Richly bittersweet with brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The balanced finish centers around blackberry and chocolate notes.
Coffee Origin: La Coipa, San Ignacio, Cajamarca, Peru
Blind Assessment: Multi-layered, deep-toned. Dark chocolate, blackberry marjoram, praline, cedar in aroma and cup. Richly bittersweet with brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The balanced finish centers around blackberry and chocolate notes.
Notes: Produced by Maria Nieves from trees of the Bourbon, Caturra and Typica varieties of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Founded in 1990, Roadmap CoffeeWorks, formerly Lexington Coffee Roasters, is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Lexington, Virginia. Roadmap CoffeeWorks focuses on producing fresh, distinctive and sustainable coffees. Visit www.roadmapcoffeeworks.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Bottom Line: A quietly complete Peru cup with deep berry, rich chocolate, and aromatic wood notes.

Review_Description: Richly sweet-tart. Black currant, hazelnut, cocoa nib, freesia, maple syrup, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy acidity; silky, viscous mouthfeel. Floral-toned finish with cedar undertones.
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-tart. Black currant, hazelnut, cocoa nib, freesia, maple syrup, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy acidity; silky, viscous mouthfeel. Floral-toned finish with cedar undertones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Kagumo Farmers Cooperative Society, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit www.revelcoffee.com or call 406-534-9621 for more information.
Bottom Line: A classic Kenya cup with particularly inviting, juicy-bright acidity grounded by engaging black currant notes, the hallmark of the origin.

Review_Description: Crisply sweet, balanced, rich. Caramel, baking chocolate, orange bitters, hazelnut butter, pie cherry in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of creamy hazelnut and orange
Coffee Origin: Wamena growing region, West Papua, New Guinea
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, balanced, rich. Caramel, baking chocolate, orange bitters, hazelnut butter, pie cherry in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of creamy hazelnut and orange
Notes: The first coffee from West Papua ever to be exported to North America or Europe. Processed by the conventional fully washed method, which is anomalous in this growing region, actually a province of Indonesia, where Indonesian-style washing and wet-hulling is more typical. In partnership with Cafe Imports, Roadmap is donating $7 from the sale of each bag to Grounds for Health, a non-profit that provides women’s healthcare in coffee-producing communities. Founded in 1990, Roadmap CoffeeWorks, formerly Lexington Coffee Roasters, is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Lexington, Virginia. Roadmap CoffeeWorks focuses on producing fresh, distinctive and sustainable coffees. Visit www.roadmapcoffeeworks.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Bottom Line: This conventionally washed-process coffee from West Papua, New Guinea, an Indonesian province better known for its rustic wet-hulled coffees, is sweet, complex, chocolaty and nutty.

Coffee_Name: Costa Rica Turrialba Volcano Honey Process
Review_Description: Fruit-toned, deeply sweet-tart. Blackberry, brown sugar, dark chocolate, cedar, star jasmine in aroma and cup. Bright and juicy with lively acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. Fruit-toned finish with undertones of brown sugar and cedar.
Blind Assessment: Fruit-toned, deeply sweet-tart. Blackberry, brown sugar, dark chocolate, cedar, star jasmine in aroma and cup. Bright and juicy with lively acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. Fruit-toned finish with undertones of brown sugar and cedar.
Notes: Produced on the slopes of Turrialba Volcano at Aquiares Farm, and processed by the honey method (some of the fruit flesh is left on the bean while drying). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit www.buoncaffe.com.tw for more information.
Bottom Line: A richly fruit-toned honey-processed Ethiopia cup centered around notes of berries and spice-toned florals.

Review_Description: Balanced, richly sweet. Apricot, baking chocolate, almond, Meyer lemon zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with bright, juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of cocoa-toned almond and bittersweet lemon zest.
Blind Assessment: Balanced, richly sweet. Apricot, baking chocolate, almond, Meyer lemon zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with bright, juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of cocoa-toned almond and bittersweet lemon zest.
Notes: Produced by members of the Adame Garbota Cooperative and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit www.buoncaffe.com.tw for more information.
Bottom Line: An inviting washed Ethiopia cup with depth from cocoa notes and a rich bittersweetness from citrus zest.

Review_Description: Gently fruit-toned. Dried cranberry, agave syrup, freesia, cedar, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with brisk acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Quietly fruity finish with undertones of spicy florals.
Blind Assessment: Gently fruit-toned. Dried cranberry, agave syrup, freesia, cedar, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with brisk acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Quietly fruity finish with undertones of spicy florals.
Notes: Produced by Newerley Gutierrez of Finca Monteverde, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Yipao Coffee Roasters, based in San Diego, was founded by two native Colombians who specialize in single-origin Colombia coffees. Visit www.yipao-coffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A balanced, easygoing natural-processed Colombia Geisha with engaging fruit, floral and herb notes.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe Gedeb Worka Chelchele
Review_Description: High-toned, richly sweet-savory. Plum, tangerine, narcissus, cedar, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Vibrant structure with balanced, juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The resonant finish consolidates to notes of plum and tangerine supported by maple syrup suggestions.
Blind Assessment: High-toned, richly sweet-savory. Plum, tangerine, narcissus, cedar, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Vibrant structure with balanced, juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The resonant finish consolidates to notes of plum and tangerine supported by maple syrup suggestions.
Notes: Coffees like this one from the Yirgacheffe growing region are largely produced from selections of traditional Ethiopian landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a wet-processed or “washed” version (fruit skin and flesh are removed before drying). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Bottom Line: A juicy, citrus- and floral-toned washed Ethiopia as deep as it is bright.

Review_Description: Complex, deep-toned. Apricot, pink grapefruit zest, salted caramel, cedar, lemon thyme in aroma and cup. Crisp, sweetly tart structure with juicy acidity; satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of pink grapefruit, apricot and cedar.
Blind Assessment: Complex, deep-toned. Apricot, pink grapefruit zest, salted caramel, cedar, lemon thyme in aroma and cup. Crisp, sweetly tart structure with juicy acidity; satiny mouthfeel. Finish consolidates to notes of pink grapefruit, apricot and cedar.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Bargain Cafe is a specialty coffee roaster in Taitung, Taiwan. Visit https://shopee.tw/iamjiter for more information.
Bottom Line: A washed Ethiopia redolent of stone fruit and salted caramel; juicy-sweet and rich.

Review_Description: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly roast-rounded. Baking chocolate, lily, prune, gently scorched oak, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Crisp, full mouthfeel; chocolaty finish with undertones of orange zest. In three parts milk, richly chocolaty and deep, elevated by notes of sweet florals and orange zest.
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly roast-rounded. Baking chocolate, lily, prune, gently scorched oak, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Crisp, full mouthfeel; chocolaty finish with undertones of orange zest. In three parts milk, richly chocolaty and deep, elevated by notes of sweet florals and orange zest.
Notes: A blend comprised of coffees from Indonesia, Colombia and Guatemala, roasted for espresso applications. SanFull Coffee Roasters, based in Taoyuan City Taiwan, is a specialty coffee roaster founded in 1988. Visit www.sanfullcoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A pleasing darker-roasted espresso blend with gentle roast notes, lots of chocolate, and sweet florals throughout. At its best in cappuccino format.

Review_Description: Aromatic, sweet-savory, big-bodied. Grapefruit, dark chocolate, cedar, sarsaparilla, ginger blossom in aroma and cup. Sweetly brisk with plush, viscous mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a simple, resonant finish around notes of grapefruit and cedar.
Blind Assessment: Aromatic, sweet-savory, big-bodied. Grapefruit, dark chocolate, cedar, sarsaparilla, ginger blossom in aroma and cup. Sweetly brisk with plush, viscous mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a simple, resonant finish around notes of grapefruit and cedar.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees largely from selections of indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This example is processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed before drying). RamsHead Coffee Roasters is a family-owned company founded by Bozeman, Montana natives Caleb and Laura Walker that specializes in direct trade microlot coffees. For more information, visit www.ramsheadcoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A hearty washed Ethiopia characterized by sweet-tart grapefruit and richly aromatic cedar, softened by dark chocolate tones.

Coffee_Name: Colombia Huila Finca El Triunfo Martha Zuñiga Pink Bourbon
Review_Description: Richly aromatic, deep-toned. Wild strawberry, lemon curd, roasted almond, narcissus, tangerine zest in aroma and small cup. Bright and juicy with sparkling acidity; full, satiny mouthfeel. The long finish centers around notes of lemon curd and almond.
Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, deep-toned. Wild strawberry, lemon curd, roasted almond, narcissus, tangerine zest in aroma and small cup. Bright and juicy with sparkling acidity; full, satiny mouthfeel. The long finish centers around notes of lemon curd and almond.
Notes: Produced by Martha Zuñiga of Finca El Triunfo, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in an oxygen-free environment before drying. RamsHead Coffee Roasters is a family-owned company founded by Bozeman, Montana natives Caleb and Laura Walker that specializes in direct trade microlot coffees. For more information, visit www.ramsheadcoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A delightfully deep yet playful anaerobic natural Colombia Pink Bourbon that demonstrates varietal character throughout the cup — juicy, fruity, balanced.

Review_Description: Fruit-forward, balanced and juicy. Dried apricot, dark chocolate, pink grapefruit zest, hazelnut brittle, lemon verbena in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with brisk acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The resonant finish leads with notes of dried apricot and hazelnut.
Blind Assessment: Fruit-forward, balanced and juicy. Dried apricot, dark chocolate, pink grapefruit zest, hazelnut brittle, lemon verbena in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with brisk acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The resonant finish leads with notes of dried apricot and hazelnut.
Notes: Produced at Finca Mirazu, entirely of the SL28 variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Coffeeland is a specialty coffee roastery with two locations, one in Chia-Yi, Taiwan, and one in Ontario, California. Visit www.coffeeland.com/tw.
Bottom Line: Produced from trees of the admired SL28 variety, originating in Kenya but grown in Costa Rica, here processed by the natural method: juicy, chocolaty, citrusy and deep.

Review_Description: Sweet, cocoa-toned, wood-framed. Cocoa powder, raisin, cashew, elm, shiitake mushroom in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The quiet finish consolidates to notes of cashew and fir.
Blind Assessment: Sweet, cocoa-toned, wood-framed. Cocoa powder, raisin, cashew, elm, shiitake mushroom in aroma and cup. Briskly sweet acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The quiet finish consolidates to notes of cashew and fir.
Notes: A blend comprised of coffees from five origins: Ethiopia, Brazil, India, Indonesia and Guatemala. Heat Coffee is a nano-roaster in Taipei, Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest-quality coffee. Visit https://www.facebook.com/heatcoffee768 for more information.
Bottom Line: A friendly, accessible blend with warm earth and crisp cocoa tones supported by rich aromatic wood.

Review_Description: Bright, crisp, sweet-toned. Almond brittle, Pink Lady apple, baking chocolate, oak, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; plush, viscous mouthfeel. Crisp, sweetly nutty finish.
Coffee Origin: San Martin Jilotepeque, Chimaltenango Department, Guatemala
Blind Assessment: Bright, crisp, sweet-toned. Almond brittle, Pink Lady apple, baking chocolate, oak, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; plush, viscous mouthfeel. Crisp, sweetly nutty finish.
Notes: Produced by Anthony Medina of Finca La Colina, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Imported by Primavera Coffee. Succulent Coffee Roasters is a Southern California specialty roaster and coffee shop founded in 2019. Visit www.succulentcoffeeroasters.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A straight-ahead, comfortable Guatemala cup with a throughline of sweet nut and crisp apple notes and an especially rich mouthfeel.

Review_Description: Balanced, floral, sweetly spice-toned. Magnolia, almond butter, ginger cookie, sugarcane, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned with brisk acidity; lightly satiny, very smooth mouthfeel. The crisp, richly sweet finish centers around sugarcane and almond.
Blind Assessment: Balanced, floral, sweetly spice-toned. Magnolia, almond butter, ginger cookie, sugarcane, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned with brisk acidity; lightly satiny, very smooth mouthfeel. The crisp, richly sweet finish centers around sugarcane and almond.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers of the Bukeye Commune, entirely of Bourbon-related varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Imported by Kafe Kreyol. Succulent Coffee Roasters is a Southern California specialty roaster and coffee shop founded in 2019. Visit www.succulentcoffeeroasters.com for more information
Bottom Line: An attractively complex, deeply layered, floral- and spice-toned Burundi.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia Bench-Maji Lucy Station Washed Geisha
Review_Description: Multi-layered, sweetly tart. Freesia, pink grapefruit zest, nectarine, cedar, bay leaf in aroma and cup. Crisp, sweetly tart structure with bright acidity; delicate, silky mouthfeel. Pink grapefruit, nectarine and cedar notes carry the crisp finish.
Blind Assessment: Multi-layered, sweetly tart. Freesia, pink grapefruit zest, nectarine, cedar, bay leaf in aroma and cup. Crisp, sweetly tart structure with bright acidity; delicate, silky mouthfeel. Pink grapefruit, nectarine and cedar notes carry the crisp finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Kafe Coffee Roastery is a specialty roaster based in Zhubei, Taiwan. Visit shopee.tw/zengkaochen for more information.
Bottom Line: A floral, sweetly citrusy washed Ethiopia, richly aromatic and bright.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Faysel Abdosh Anaerobic Natural
Review_Description: Sweetly fermenty, richly aromatic. Raspberry brandy, lilac, mint, cocoa nib, yogurt in aroma and cup. Tart-leaning structure with citrusy acidity; satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Rich-toned finish with notes of mint and raspberry brandy.
Coffee Origin: Ethiopia Sidamo Faysel Abdosh Anaerobic Natural
Blind Assessment: Sweetly fermenty, richly aromatic. Raspberry brandy, lilac, mint, cocoa nib, yogurt in aroma and cup. Tart-leaning structure with citrusy acidity; satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Rich-toned finish with notes of mint and raspberry brandy.
Notes: Produced by Faysel Abdosh, from trees of the 774110 and 74158 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in an oxygen-free environment before drying. Regent strives to deliver coffee with care and purpose. Visit regentcoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: An intentionally fermenty Ethiopia anaerobic cup with juicy berry notes, lactic tang, and sweet herbs throughout.

Review_Description: Richly sweet-savory, multi-layered. Blackberry, dark chocolate, salted caramel, fresh-cut cedar, narcissus in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweet-savory structure with juicy-bright acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. The long finish leads with dark chocolate and narcissus.
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory, multi-layered. Blackberry, dark chocolate, salted caramel, fresh-cut cedar, narcissus in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweet-savory structure with juicy-bright acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. The long finish leads with dark chocolate and narcissus.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Ngariama Cooperative Society, from trees of the SL28, Ruiru 11 and Batian varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was named the “2012 Micro-Roaster of the Year” by Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
Bottom Line: This classic Kenya displays dark berry and rich chocolate notes vibrantlly juxtaposed with spicy florals and salted caramel.

Review_Description: Balanced, bright, deep-toned. Pomegranate, Graham cracker, tangerine, baking chocolate, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with lively acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of tangerine and baking chocolate with undertones of cedar.
Blind Assessment: Balanced, bright, deep-toned. Pomegranate, Graham cracker, tangerine, baking chocolate, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with lively acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of tangerine and baking chocolate with undertones of cedar.
Notes: Produced by Juan Diego de la Cerda, entirely of the Maracaturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Maracaturra is a cross between the huge-beaned Maragogipe and the compact-growing Caturra varieties of Arabica. Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was named the “2012 Micro-Roaster of the Year” by Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
Bottom Line: A harmonious, integrated Guatemala Maracaturra with elegant depth and perky acidity.

Review_Description: Chocolaty, floral-driven. Baking chocolate, honeysuckle, fig newton, lemon verbena, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Baking chocolate and honeysuckle, supported by cedar, carry the finish.
Blind Assessment: Chocolaty, floral-driven. Baking chocolate, honeysuckle, fig newton, lemon verbena, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Baking chocolate and honeysuckle, supported by cedar, carry the finish.
Notes: Produced by Luis Pedro Zelaya Zamora entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Bottom Line: The deep floral character of this Guatemala is supported by crisp chocolate and sweet herb. Particularly plush, viscous mouthfeel.

Review_Description: Fruit- and cocoa-toned. Raspberry, cocoa nib, thyme, cedar, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with even-keeled acidity; plush, very syrupy mouthfeel. Jammy, herbaceous finish.
Blind Assessment: Fruit- and cocoa-toned. Raspberry, cocoa nib, thyme, cedar, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with even-keeled acidity; plush, very syrupy mouthfeel. Jammy, herbaceous finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers surrounding Huye Mountain Washing Station, entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Bottom Line: A confident, familiar, satisfying Rwanda with notes of red berry up front, complicated by pleasing bittersweet citrus and crisp cocoa nib throughout.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia Bench Maji Geisha Lucy Station
Review_Description: Floral-toned, sweetly citrusy. Magrut lime, star jasmine, salted almond, fresh-cut oak, honey in aroma and cup. Juicy-sweet structure with brightly tart acidity; very silky, viscous mouthfeel. Citrusy and floral-toned finish.
Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, sweetly citrusy. Magrut lime, star jasmine, salted almond, fresh-cut oak, honey in aroma and cup. Juicy-sweet structure with brightly tart acidity; very silky, viscous mouthfeel. Citrusy and floral-toned finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It is processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). GK Coffee is a nano-roastery in Yilan, Taiwan that offers both retail and wholesale coffee. For more information, visit www.gkcoffee.com.tw or email [email protected]
Bottom Line: A very pretty washed Ethiopia Geisha with complex citrus and spice-toned florals, and a compelling umami undercurrent.

Review_Description: Balanced, bright, juicy. Lemon curd, salted caramel, bosc pear, almond brittle, star jasmine in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with high-toned acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Resonant, lingering, integrated finish.
Blind Assessment: Balanced, bright, juicy. Lemon curd, salted caramel, bosc pear, almond brittle, star jasmine in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with high-toned acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Resonant, lingering, integrated finish.
Notes: Produced by five smallholding farmers, from trees of the Bourbon, Typica and Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.” Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-JAVA for more information.
Bottom Line: A vibrant, harmonious Ecuador cup that leads with floral depth and richly sweet-tart fruit notes — lively and invigorating.

Coffee_Name: HWC Geisha Plus Geisha Black Espresso
Review_Description: Evaluated as espresso. Richly floral, cocoa-toned. Magnolia, cocoa nib, pomegranate, molasses, marjoram in aroma and small cup. Syrupy-smooth mouthfeel; long, flavor-saturated finish. In three parts milk, cocoa notes are amplified and the tart fruit is balanced by sweet herbs and spice-toned florals.
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly floral, cocoa-toned. Magnolia, cocoa nib, pomegranate, molasses, marjoram in aroma and small cup. Syrupy-smooth mouthfeel; long, flavor-saturated finish. In three parts milk, cocoa notes are amplified and the tart fruit is balanced by sweet herbs and spice-toned florals.
Notes: A blend comprised of two coffees of the Geisha variety of Arabica, one from Colombia and one from Ethiopia, both processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Roasted for espresso applications. HWC Roasters is a specialty coffee roaster based in Taichung, Taiwan. For more information, visit www.hwcroasters.com.
Bottom Line: A complex, deeply floral espresso blend composed of Geishas from two different origins. Especially satisfying and cocoa-driven in three-parts milk.

Review_Description: Brightly sweet, high-toned. Pink grapefruit, cocoa nib, red plum, maple syrup, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy acidity; very silky, vibrant mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and pink grapefruit.
Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet, high-toned. Pink grapefruit, cocoa nib, red plum, maple syrup, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy acidity; very silky, vibrant mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and pink grapefruit.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Ethiopian 74110 variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). HWC Roasters is a specialty coffee roaster based in Taichung, Taiwan. For more information, visit www.hwcroasters.com.
Bottom Line: A lively, cocoa- and stone fruit-driven washed Ethiopia with a throughline of sweet citrus notes supported by rich aromatic wood.

Review_Description: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly nut-toned. Cashew butter, baking chocolate, sassafras, date, gardenia in aroma and small cup. Crisp mouthfeel; gently drying, floral finish. Chocolaty and nutty in cappuccino-scaled milk.
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly nut-toned. Cashew butter, baking chocolate, sassafras, date, gardenia in aroma and small cup. Crisp mouthfeel; gently drying, floral finish. Chocolaty and nutty in cappuccino-scaled milk.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Honduras, Ethiopia and Brazil, roasted for espresso applications. HWC Roasters is a specialty coffee roaster based in Taichung, Taiwan. For more information, visit www.hwcroasters.com.
Bottom Line: A straight-ahead, medium-dark espresso blend with creamy nut and crisp chocolate notes throughout.

Coffee_Name: Panama Boquete Casa Ruiz Finca Cafelandia Pacamara
Review_Description: Complex, sweetly herbaceous. Tamarind, cocoa nib, vanilla bean, freesia, lemon-thyme in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with brisk acidity; viscous, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The crisp finish leads with notes of freesia and lemon-thyme.
Blind Assessment: Complex, sweetly herbaceous. Tamarind, cocoa nib, vanilla bean, freesia, lemon-thyme in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with brisk acidity; viscous, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The crisp finish leads with notes of freesia and lemon-thyme.
Notes: Produced at Casa Ruiz, entirely of the Pacamara variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Libero Coffee is a specialty coffee shop and roaster in Taipei. Visit www.facebook.com/LiberoCoffeeBar/?locale=zh_TW for more information.
Bottom Line: A multi-layered washed Panama Pacamara, sweetly savory and richly herbaceous with undertones of cocoa nib and tamarind.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia Gediyo Yirgacheffe Gedeb Banko Gotiti G1 Natural
Review_Description: Crisp, fruit-toned, delicately floral. Baking chocolate, lime zest, date, narcissus, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned with brisk acidity; crisply satiny mouthfeel. Gently drying finish with aromatic wood notes supported by lime zest.
Blind Assessment: Crisp, fruit-toned, delicately floral. Baking chocolate, lime zest, date, narcissus, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned with brisk acidity; crisply satiny mouthfeel. Gently drying finish with aromatic wood notes supported by lime zest.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from selections of indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Libero Coffee is a specialty coffee shop and roaster in Taipei. Visit www.facebook.com/LiberoCoffeeBar/?locale=zh_TW for more information.
Bottom Line: A quietly balanced, crisply chocolaty natural Ethiopia cup with rich aromatic wood notes throughout.

Review_Description: Honey-sweet and spice-toned. Baking spices, honey, dark chocolate, lavender, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet in structure with a balancing tart and savory edge. Very smooth, silky-satiny mouthfeel. Balanced and comprehensive in the finish, alive with all of the notes from the cup.
Blind Assessment: Honey-sweet and spice-toned. Baking spices, honey, dark chocolate, lavender, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet in structure with a balancing tart and savory edge. Very smooth, silky-satiny mouthfeel. Balanced and comprehensive in the finish, alive with all of the notes from the cup.
Notes: Produced on the Blue Sunda farm and processed by the traditional Indonesian wet-hulled method. Imported by Genuine Origins. Peach Coffee Roasters is an Atlanta, Georgia-based specialty roaster. Visit www.peachcoffeeroasters.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A striking yet reassuring cup, original in structure and aromatics yet gracefully complete, without overstatement.

Review_Description: Deep, sweet, brandy-toned. Bittersweet chocolate, star jasmine, raisin, brandy, ripe banana in aroma and cup. Quite sweet in structure, with a balancing bitter edge. Big, plush mouthfeel. Chocolate and brandy particularly resonate in a rich finish.
Blind Assessment: Deep, sweet, brandy-toned. Bittersweet chocolate, star jasmine, raisin, brandy, ripe banana in aroma and cup. Quite sweet in structure, with a balancing bitter edge. Big, plush mouthfeel. Chocolate and brandy particularly resonate in a rich finish.
Notes: Produced by small-holding farmers operating within the traditional Balinese spiritual, social and ecological system called Subak Abian and processed by the natural method (beans are dried in the whole fruit). Organic and Rainforest Alliance certified. Founded by Brad Katz, a music lover and home coffee roaster, Bassline Coffee aims to offer something for every kind of coffee lover with roasts that bring out the inherent qualities of diverse green coffees. Visit www.basslinecoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A fine, cleanly expressed natural in the old-fashioned sweet, brandy-toned style. Lovely, quietly lush floral notes as well.

Review_Description: Tangy-sweet, brisk. Concord grape, lime zest, pistachio, musky rose, sourdough rye in aroma and cup. Briskly bright in structure; full and syrupy in mouthfeel. The finish is crisp, rich and tangy-sour.
Blind Assessment: Tangy-sweet, brisk. Concord grape, lime zest, pistachio, musky rose, sourdough rye in aroma and cup. Briskly bright in structure; full and syrupy in mouthfeel. The finish is crisp, rich and tangy-sour.
Notes: Frinsa Estate is owned by a couple, Wildan Mustofa, who directs and oversees operational activities (farms and processing) and Atieq Mustikaningtyas, who manages human resources and finances. Frinsa Estate grows, guides partnering farmers, collects, and processes specialty coffee from the Bandung highlands region. This coffee is produced from the Ateng variety of Arabica and processed by the natural method (beans are dried in the whole fruit). Corvus particularly focuses on processing methods and selective harvesting, which results in small, seasonal micro-lots of uniquely sweet, vibrant, and clean flavor profiles. For more information, visit www.corvuscoffee.com.
Bottom Line: Here the natural processing method encourages a brisk, bright cup rounded by grape, pistachio and musky flowers.

Review_Description: Sweetly tart and cocoa-toned. Pineapple, cocoa, violet, agave syrup, hazelnut in aroma and cup. Gently and brightly sweet-tart in structure; smooth and lively in mouthfeel. Cocoa and pineapple carry into a sweet, quiet finish.
Coffee Origin: Tlogosari Village, Argopuro, East Java, Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart and cocoa-toned. Pineapple, cocoa, violet, agave syrup, hazelnut in aroma and cup. Gently and brightly sweet-tart in structure; smooth and lively in mouthfeel. Cocoa and pineapple carry into a sweet, quiet finish.
Notes: Produced by small-holding members of the Pokmas Walida Cooperative, working with Belift Green Beans, an Indonesia-based grassroots coffee exporter that advised the cooperative on processing this coffee using the anaerobic natural method (coffee in the whole fruit is fermented in an oxygen-free environment before drying in the whole fruit). Founded in 1995 by Brooke McDonnell and Helen Russell, Equator Coffees operates retail stores in the San Francisco Bay Area and southern California and provides coffee to hundreds of wholesale accounts. Visit www.equatorcoffees.com or call 800-809-7687 for more information.
Bottom Line: Anaerobic natural processing nicely sweetens and brightens the profile, and encourages a particularly wide range of aroma and flavor notes. A quietly complete coffee that should satisfy those looking for both familiarity and excitement.

Review_Description: Sweet, deep, tobacco-toned. Sweet pipe tobacco, date, cedar, baking chocolate, freesia in aroma and cup. Balanced in structure, gently sweet-tart. Syrupy in mouthfeel; date, cedar, a hint of sweet tobacco in the finish.
Blind Assessment: Sweet, deep, tobacco-toned. Sweet pipe tobacco, date, cedar, baking chocolate, freesia in aroma and cup. Balanced in structure, gently sweet-tart. Syrupy in mouthfeel; date, cedar, a hint of sweet tobacco in the finish.
Notes: Produced by small-holding farmers operating within the traditional Balinese spiritual, social and ecological system called Subak Abian, from the Typica, Bourbon and Catimor varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional Indonesian wet-hulled method. Based in southern Oregon, Noble Coffee Roasting is a wholesale and retail roasting company focused on quality, social responsibility and environmental awareness. Visit www.noblecoffeeroasting.com or call 541-488-3288 for more information.
Bottom Line: Sumatra lite; nods with quiet delicacy toward the cedary, tobacco-toned depth we associate with wet-hulled Sumatras.

Review_Description: Deep, savory-sweet, balanced. Sweet pipe tobacco, nut melange, oak, hints of lily and tamarind in aroma and cup. Brisk and tart-savory in structure, with a cushion of sweetness. Light but silky in mouthfeel. The finish consolidates around hints of tobacco and tamarind.
Blind Assessment: Deep, savory-sweet, balanced. Sweet pipe tobacco, nut melange, oak, hints of lily and tamarind in aroma and cup. Brisk and tart-savory in structure, with a cushion of sweetness. Light but silky in mouthfeel. The finish consolidates around hints of tobacco and tamarind.
Notes: Processed by the traditional Indonesian wet-hulled method. Small Eyes Cafe is a small, family-owned coffee shop in Yilan, Taiwan, specializing in artisanally roasted specialty coffee and homemade desserts. Visit www.facebook.com/Smalleyescafe for more information.
Bottom Line: Fans of deep, earthy wet-hulled Sumatras may enjoy this subtle variation on the style: nutty and oaky with fragrant hints of moist tobacco and sweet lily.

Review_Description: Tangy-sweet and richly savory. Cocoa, macadamia, raspberry, fennel, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Deep, savory-tangy in structure; lightly syrupy and lively in mouthfeel. Cocoa and macadamia dominate in the short finish, but a delicate raspberry carries the long.
Blind Assessment: Tangy-sweet and richly savory. Cocoa, macadamia, raspberry, fennel, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Deep, savory-tangy in structure; lightly syrupy and lively in mouthfeel. Cocoa and macadamia dominate in the short finish, but a delicate raspberry carries the long.
Notes: Produced by small-holding farmers operating within the traditional Balinese spiritual, social and ecological system called Subak Abian and processed by the natural method (beans are dried in the whole fruit). Imported by Royal Coffee, Oakland, California. Succulent Coffee Roasters is a southern California specialty roaster and coffee shop founded in 2019. Visit www.succulentcoffeeroasters.com for more information.
Bottom Line: Expresses the sweet-savory nut and cocoa side of natural processing, enlivened by a shimmer of tart fruit.

Coffee_Name: Bali Yeast Honey Edi Kadek Lot
Review_Description: Caramelly, delicately sweet-savory. Peach, caramel, shiitake, redwood, clover flowers in aroma and cup. Gently brisk and sweet-tart in structure; satiny in mouthfeel. The finish is wispy and delicate: peach and caramel.
Blind Assessment: Caramelly, delicately sweet-savory. Peach, caramel, shiitake, redwood, clover flowers in aroma and cup. Gently brisk and sweet-tart in structure; satiny in mouthfeel. The finish is wispy and delicate: peach and caramel.
Notes: Produced in the central highlands of Bali from the S795 variety of Arabica and processed by a hybrid method involving fermentation with cultured yeasts before drying with the “honey” or fruit flesh still adhering to the beans. Kopi Ibrik is a tiny, boutique coffee roaster and cafe in Taiwan that aims to synthesize the Turkish coffee brewing tradition with contemporary specialty coffee attitudes and practices. Visit www.instagram.com/kopi_ibrik for more information.
Bottom Line: Walks a delicate, engaging line between caramelly sweetness and shiitake-like savory, with a hint of flowers at the top.

Review_Description: Crisply chocolaty, sweetly nut-toned. Baking chocolate, cashew, orange zest, date, gardenia in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned with gentle acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. The gently drying finish centers around bittersweet chocolate notes.
Blind Assessment: Crisply chocolaty, sweetly nut-toned. Baking chocolate, cashew, orange zest, date, gardenia in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned with gentle acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. The gently drying finish centers around bittersweet chocolate notes.
Notes: Produced and roasted by Finca El Rey in Veracruz, Mexico. Certified USDA Organic. Founded in 1954 by Italian immigrants, Finca El Rey is still family-owned and operated by third-generation Reynaldo Bernardi. Visit soloalto.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A friendly, accessible Mexico cup: richly chocolaty and supported by sweet nut, fruit and floral tones.

Review_Description: Fruit-forward, intensely sweet. Watermelon candy, tangy kefir, salted plum, raw chocolate, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with sparkling acidity; plush, very syrupy mouthfeel. A long, complex finish fulfills the promise of the cup.
Blind Assessment: Fruit-forward, intensely sweet. Watermelon candy, tangy kefir, salted plum, raw chocolate, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with sparkling acidity; plush, very syrupy mouthfeel. A long, complex finish fulfills the promise of the cup.
Notes: Produced by Juan Peña of Finca La Papaya, entirely of the Typica variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method with the addition of a yeast-inoculated fermentation step. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information
Bottom Line: A uniquely composed experimentally processed Ecuador cup that’s a roller-coaster of aroma and flavor — an exhilarating ride.

Review_Description: Complex, multi-layered. Nectarine, freesia, hop flowers, agave syrup, basil in aroma and cup. Sweetly savory with high-toned acidity; plush, viscous mouthfeel. Resonant, lingering, flavor-saturated finish.
Blind Assessment: Complex, multi-layered. Nectarine, freesia, hop flowers, agave syrup, basil in aroma and cup. Sweetly savory with high-toned acidity; plush, viscous mouthfeel. Resonant, lingering, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Macarena Farm entirely of the Tabi variety of Arabica. Processed by a complex double fermentation method, in which ​​the coffee fruit is first sterilized, then fermented anaerobically in the whole fruit in a bio-reactor with added microorganisms. After this fermentation in the whole fruit, the coffee is pulped and subjected to a second fermentation, after which the beans are sealed through the impact of hot and cold water before washing and careful drying by machine for 36 hours. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information
Bottom Line: An invigoratingly bright anaerobic Colombia grounded by rich savory impulses with compelling complications.

Review_Description: Chocolaty, deeply rich. Dark chocolate, vanilla bean, yellow plum, cashew butter, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet with vibrant, juicy acidity; viscous, richly satiny mouthfeel. A long finish consolidates to notes of vanilla bean and cashew butter.
Blind Assessment: Chocolaty, deeply rich. Dark chocolate, vanilla bean, yellow plum, cashew butter, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet with vibrant, juicy acidity; viscous, richly satiny mouthfeel. A long finish consolidates to notes of vanilla bean and cashew butter.
Notes: Produced by Eulogia Carrillo Julca of Finca El Mango, from trees of the Caturra, Pache and Typica varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Certified Organic and Fair Trade, and a “JBC Female-Forward Coffee.” JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Bottom Line: A bright, deep-toned, richly sweet and very satisfying women-farmed washed Ecuador cup.

Review_Description: Richly aromatic, deep-toned. Lemongrass, mandarin orange, maple syrup, almond butter, narcissus in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with confidently bright acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Harmonious, integrated, flavor-laden finish.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, deep-toned. Lemongrass, mandarin orange, maple syrup, almond butter, narcissus in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with confidently bright acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Harmonious, integrated, flavor-laden finish.
Notes: Produced by Daniel Mijane and smallholding farmers surrounding the Sakaro Washing Station, from trees of heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information
Bottom Line: A classic washed Ethiopia cup: juicy, bright, citrusy and floral.

Review_Description: Sweetly herbaceous and juicy-bright. Black cherry, lemon-thyme, cocoa nib, frankincense, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Very sweet with vibrant, juicy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and lemon-thyme.
Blind Assessment: Sweetly herbaceous and juicy-bright. Black cherry, lemon-thyme, cocoa nib, frankincense, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Very sweet with vibrant, juicy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and lemon-thyme.
Notes: Produced by Jose Roberto Monterroso of Finca El Morito, entirely of the Pacamara variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information
Bottom Line: A citrusy and stone fruit-driven, impressively complex washed Guatemala cup.

Review_Description: Sweet and lively. Tea rose, salted caramel, watermelon, fresh-cut fir, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Sweetly savory with brisk acidity; very full, satiny mouthfeel. Crisp finish with notes of tea rose and fresh-cut fir.
Coffee Origin: South Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo
Blind Assessment: Sweet and lively. Tea rose, salted caramel, watermelon, fresh-cut fir, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Sweetly savory with brisk acidity; very full, satiny mouthfeel. Crisp finish with notes of tea rose and fresh-cut fir.
Notes: Certified organic and fair trade. Produced by members of the SOPACDI Cooperative, from the Blue Mountain, Bourbon, Caturra and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Located overlooking Lake Kivu, on the opposite side of the lake from Rwanda, this rapidly growing cooperative now has nearly 6,000 members and is succeeding in its goal to help heal wounds left by the latest in eastern Congo’s seemingly endless string of civil wars. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information
Bottom Line: A deeply aromatic washed DR Congo cup with a profile is focused around floral and melon notes, with pleasing umami undertones.

Review_Description: Richly sweet-savory, spice-toned. Cocoa nib, clove, ginger root, dark chocolate, graphite in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with juicy, balanced acidity; deep, creamy mouthfeel. Long-lasting, spice-driven, richly sweet finish.
Coffee Origin: Pegasing, Takengon, Aceh Province, Sumatra, Indonesia
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory, spice-toned. Cocoa nib, clove, ginger root, dark chocolate, graphite in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with juicy, balanced acidity; deep, creamy mouthfeel. Long-lasting, spice-driven, richly sweet finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Gayo 1, Gayo 2, Catimor and Abyssinia varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Bottom Line: An enticingly savory, richly sweet washed Sumatra cup that offers spice suggestions and crisp chocolate with mineral undertones.

Review_Description: Savory-sweet, deep and juicy. Pomegranate, ginger flower, dark chocolate, pomelo zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with cola-like, phosphoric acidity; viscous, creamy mouthfeel. Flavor-saturated finish — long, chocolaty, fruity and spice-toned.
Blind Assessment: Savory-sweet, deep and juicy. Pomegranate, ginger flower, dark chocolate, pomelo zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with cola-like, phosphoric acidity; viscous, creamy mouthfeel. Flavor-saturated finish — long, chocolaty, fruity and spice-toned.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers of the Giakanja Farmers Cooperative Society, from trees of the SL34, SL28 Ruiru 11 and Batian varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information
Bottom Line: This Kenya hits all the notes: tart fruit, spicy florals, rich chocolate, pleasing aromatic wood and complex citrus.

Review_Description: Balanced, crisply sweet. Dark chocolate, pistachio, date, wisteria, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned with gently bright acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. A sweet finish consolidates to notes of dark chocolate and pistachio.
Blind Assessment: Balanced, crisply sweet. Dark chocolate, pistachio, date, wisteria, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned with gently bright acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. A sweet finish consolidates to notes of dark chocolate and pistachio.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Asomombo Cooperative, entirely of the Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information
Bottom Line: A sweet, chocolaty washed Colombia cup, inviting in its familiarity and depth, with intriguing savory nut underpinnings (think pistachio).

Review_Description: Crisply sweet-savory, berry-toned. Raspberry, baking chocolate, almond, fir, sarsaparilla in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with brisk acidity; very full, creamy mouthfeel. Gently drying wood-framed finish with chocolate undertones.
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory, berry-toned. Raspberry, baking chocolate, almond, fir, sarsaparilla in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with brisk acidity; very full, creamy mouthfeel. Gently drying wood-framed finish with chocolate undertones.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of Proyecto Cabanas in the Southern part of Honduras bordering El Salvador, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which whole cherries are fermented in an oxygen-free environment before being dried in the whole fruit. True Coffee is a specialty roaster and cafe in Wisconsin whose motto is, “On a never-ending quest to bring you a great cup of coffee, by staying true to the bean.” Visit www.truecoffeeroasters.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A crisply berry-driven anaerobic natural Honduras, with pleasing almond and chocolate complications.

Review_Description: Floral, fruity, chocolaty. Blueberry, star jasmine, dark chocolate, hazelnut brittle, pomelo in aroma and cup. Deeply sweet structure with sparkling acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. Chocolaty and fruit-toned in the very long and satisfying finish.
Blind Assessment: Floral, fruity, chocolaty. Blueberry, star jasmine, dark chocolate, hazelnut brittle, pomelo in aroma and cup. Deeply sweet structure with sparkling acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. Chocolaty and fruit-toned in the very long and satisfying finish.
Notes: Produced by Basha Bekele, from selections of indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Founded in 1990, Roadmap CoffeeWorks, formerly Lexington Coffee Roasters, is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Lexington, Virginia. Roadmap CoffeeWorks focuses on producing fresh, distinctive and sustainable coffees. Visit www.roadmapcoffeeworks.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Bottom Line: At the center of this pretty natural-processed Ethiopia is a melange of bright stone fruit and rich spice-toned florals grounded by deep chocolate, a winning aromatic and flavor profile.

Coffee_Name: Colombia Luz Helena Salazar Wine Yeast Grape Honey
Review_Description: Sweetly spice-toned. Concord grape, ginger blossom, baking chocolate, lemon verbena, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Gently vibrant structure with a fruity/juicy acidity; viscous, satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish, supported by notes of lemon verbena and maple syrup.
Blind Assessment: Sweetly spice-toned. Concord grape, ginger blossom, baking chocolate, lemon verbena, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Gently vibrant structure with a fruity/juicy acidity; viscous, satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish, supported by notes of lemon verbena and maple syrup.
Notes: Produced by Luz Helena Salazar, entirely of the Castillo variety of Arabica, and fermented with wine yeasts before drying by the honey method (some fruit flesh is left on the beans during drying). GK Coffee is a nano-roastery in Yilan, Taiwan that offers both retail and wholesale coffee. For more information, visit www.gkcoffee.com.tw or email [email protected]
Bottom Line: A Colombia Castillo experimentally fermented with wine yeasts— spice-toned and lively with an especially viscous mouthfeel.

Review_Description: Juicy, vibrant, fruit-forward. Mulberry, ginger blossom, cocoa nib, toffee, amber in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Long, flavor-laden finish that fulfills the promise of the cup.
Coffee Origin: Ka‘ū growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Juicy, vibrant, fruit-forward. Mulberry, ginger blossom, cocoa nib, toffee, amber in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Long, flavor-laden finish that fulfills the promise of the cup.
Notes: Produced by JN Farms from trees of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by a malolactic fermentation method designed by Miguel Meza, in which whole fruit is inoculated with both yeasts and malolactic bacteria, then fermented in anaerobic conditions for about a week before being dried in the whole fruit. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Bottom Line: A juicy, fruity, floral-toned Ka‘ū  cup processed by malolactic fermentation, a technique commonly used in wine that results in a coffee with concentrated berry and spicy floral notes.

Review_Description: Deep-toned, richly chocolaty and fruit-forward. Raspberry jam, chocolate fudge, tamarind, frangipane, gently scorched oak in aroma and small cup. Creamy-smooth mouthfeel; long, flavor-laden finish that leads with berry notes and chocolate notes. In cappuccino format, explosively chocolaty and intensely fruity.
Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, richly chocolaty and fruit-forward. Raspberry jam, chocolate fudge, tamarind, frangipane, gently scorched oak in aroma and small cup. Creamy-smooth mouthfeel; long, flavor-laden finish that leads with berry notes and chocolate notes. In cappuccino format, explosively chocolaty and intensely fruity.
Notes: Evaluated as espresso. A blend of coffees from Ethiopia (one washed and one natural-processed) and Kenya, roasted for espresso applications. In addition to his retail roasting operation, Aroma Roast Coffees, Simon Hsieh also operates Soaring Phoenix Trading, a business focused on purpose-built commercial espresso blends and high-quality single-origin coffees. Customers can also visit the new showroom, Chateau Andy, in Taipei City. Visit www.facebook.com/4ArtsZeroDefectCoffees or call 886-0983-749876 for more information.
Bottom Line: A melange of fudge-like chocolate notes and concentrated berry fruit characterizes this espresso blend from Simon Hsieh, who specializes in darker roast profiles.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia Diima Natural Process Benti Nenka, Hambela Wamena
Review_Description: Delicately sweet-tart, cocoa-toned. Cocoa nib, pineapple, narcissus, musk, cedar in aroma and cup. Intricately sweet structure with bright acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The quiet finish consolidates to cocoa nib, narcissus and cedar.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Delicately sweet-tart, cocoa-toned. Cocoa nib, pineapple, narcissus, musk, cedar in aroma and cup. Intricately sweet structure with bright acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The quiet finish consolidates to cocoa nib, narcissus and cedar.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of the Wolisho, Kurume, 74110 and 74112 varieties of Arabica and processed at the Benti Nenka Washing Station by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Mellow is a café and nano-roastery located in Taipei, Taiwan that serves quality foods and superb coffee in a comfortable setting. Email [email protected] or call 886-2-2257-3961 for more information.
Bottom Line: A cleanly natural-processed Ethiopia cup driven by tropical fruit and floral tones, with cocoa nib as ballast throughout.

Review_Description: Richly sweet-savory. Tamarind, candycap mushroom, fresh-cut fir, grapefruit zest, freesia in aroma and cup. Bittersweet structure with brisk acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Gently drying finish centered around notes of tamarind and fresh-cut fir.
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet-savory. Tamarind, candycap mushroom, fresh-cut fir, grapefruit zest, freesia in aroma and cup. Bittersweet structure with brisk acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Gently drying finish centered around notes of tamarind and fresh-cut fir.
Notes: Produced by Claudia Samboni, entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Hub Coffee Roasters is a specialty roaster focused on single-origin coffees, with several cafes in the Reno area. Visit www.hubcoffeeroasters.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A savory-leaning Colombia cup with undertones of spicy florals and tangy tropical fruit.

Review_Description: Crisply sweet, roast-rounded. Date, orange zest, kola nut, lightly scorched cedar, vanilla bean in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with crisply bittersweet acidity; lightly velvety mouthfeel. Sweetly nut-toned finish with hints of vanilla.
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, roast-rounded. Date, orange zest, kola nut, lightly scorched cedar, vanilla bean in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with crisply bittersweet acidity; lightly velvety mouthfeel. Sweetly nut-toned finish with hints of vanilla.
Notes: Certified USDA Organic and fair trade. Producer not disclosed. Twiga Coffee is based in Sacramento, California. Ten percent of all sales are donated to organizations supporting conservation efforts. Visit www.twigacoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A friendly, crisply chocolaty, sweetly nut-toned Rwanda complicated by pleasingly bittersweet citrus zest.

Coffee_Name: Colombia Finca Paraiso Gesha Wilton Benitez
Review_Description: Delicately fruit-forward, complex, multi-layered. Bergamot, lychee, honeysuckle, lemon verbena, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Bright, richly bittersweet structure with high-toned acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Integrated, flavor-laden finish.
Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-forward, complex, multi-layered. Bergamot, lychee, honeysuckle, lemon verbena, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Bright, richly bittersweet structure with high-toned acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Integrated, flavor-laden finish.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica. Processed by the kōji method, in which the coffee fruit is first sterilized and then fermented in a bio-reactor and inoculated with a selection of Japanese kōji (Aspergillus oryzae). This mold species breaks down starch into simple sugars and is commonly used in the production of soy sauce, miso, sake and shōchū. After whole-fruit fermentation, the coffee is pulped and subjected to a second fermentation phase. A bean-sealing process follows, carried out through impacts of hot and cold water, before the beans are dried by machine for 46 hours. Founded in 2013, modcup coffee focuses on fresh roasting and distinctive natural-processed coffees. Visit modcup.com for more information.
Bottom Line: Balanced, deep, elegant and inviting, this experimentally processed Geisha is characterized by tropical fruit, bittersweet citrus, and rich aromatic wood notes.

Review_Description: Brightly sweet, deeply floral. Star jasmine, apricot, almond, caramel, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with gently bright, juicy acidity; very appealing silky mouthfeel. Floral-and nut-toned finish.

Coffee_Name: Colombia Huila La Esperanza Pink Bourbon Honey
Review_Description: Balanced, richly sweet. Black cherry, maple syrup, dark chocolate, Meyer lemon zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with lively acidity; viscous, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish, supported by notes of maple syrup and black cherry.

Coffee_Name: Colombia Antioquia El Roble Long Fermentation Washed Chiroso

Review_Description: Crisp, bittersweet, fruit-forward. Dark chocolate, black cherry, lavender, cedar, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Pleasingly bittersweet structure with high-toned acidity; full, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of dark chocolate, black cherry and cedar.
Blind Assessment: Crisp, bittersweet, fruit-forward. Dark chocolate, black cherry, lavender, cedar, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Pleasingly bittersweet structure with high-toned acidity; full, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of dark chocolate, black cherry and cedar.

Review_Description: Evaluated in brew bag format with a steeping time of 5 minutes in 8 ounces of water. Fruit-toned, very sweet. Pineapple, pink peppercorn, baking chocolate, marjoram, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with gentle, fruity acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Quietly fruit-friven finish with hints of baking chocolate and cedar.
Blind Assessment: Evaluated in brew bag format with a steeping time of 5 minutes in 8 ounces of water. Fruit-toned, very sweet. Pineapple, pink peppercorn, baking chocolate, marjoram, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with gentle, fruity acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Quietly fruit-friven finish with hints of baking chocolate and cedar.
Notes: Produced by Wilder Lazo of Finca Bella Alejandria entirely of the Geisha/Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by a version of the honey or semi-washed anaerobic method: after the removal of the fruit skin and pulp, but with the flesh or mucilage still on the bean, the coffee is fermented in hermetically sealed tanks for 200 hours. After fermentation, the coffee is sun-dried for 18 days mixed with mandarin orange peels before being rested for 25 days, then milled. Packaged in brew bag format by Wildland Coffee. Review_Description: Floral-toned, gently fermenty. Narcissus, red wine, lemon verbena, cedar, myrrh in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet with juicy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Resonant finish consolidates to notes of narcissus and red wine.

Notes: Produced by Edwin Noreña of Finca Campo Hermoso, from trees of the Yellow Bourbon and Yellow Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the carbonic maceration method, involving two fermentation phases in closed tanks injected with CO2. Review_Description: Richly fermenty, sweetly whiskey-toned. Bourbon barrel, dark chocolate, orange zest, amber, fir in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. The gently drying finish is centered around Bourbon barrel notes.

Processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). The coffee was then aged in Bourbon-seasoned oak barrels before roasting. Bottom Line: An overtly whiskey-toned Ethiopia natural cup with some pleasing chocolate notes underneath — very much a coffee for those who enjoy intentionally fermenty barrel-aging profiles.

Review_Description: Floral-driven, crisply bright. Narcissus, apricot, cocoa nib, tangerine zest, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The finish leads with notes of narcissus and apricot with undertones of cocoa nib.
Blind Assessment: Floral-driven, crisply bright. Narcissus, apricot, cocoa nib, tangerine zest, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The finish leads with notes of narcissus and apricot with undertones of cocoa nib.
Notes: Southern Ethiopia produces distinctive coffees from selections of indigenous, landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Coffees like this one, processed by the traditional wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying), typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity. Uislandscafe is a roastery in Hsinchu City, Taiwan that offers high-quality specialty coffee. For more information, visit www.u-island.com or email [email protected]

Review_Description: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply chocolaty, deep-toned. Baking chocolate, date, cashew, orange zest, molasses in aroma and small cup. Crisply smooth mouthfeel; gently drying finish with notes of orange zest and cashew. In cappuccino-scaled milk, baking chocolate predominates, supported by cashew and orange zest.
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply chocolaty, deep-toned. Baking chocolate, date, cashew, orange zest, molasses in aroma and small cup. Crisply smooth mouthfeel; gently drying finish with notes of orange zest and cashew. In cappuccino-scaled milk, baking chocolate predominates, supported by cashew and orange zest.

Coffee_Name: Organic Peru San Fernando Tres Fincas Gesha
Review_Description: Richly sweet, floral-toned. Wisteria, red plum, cocoa nib, hazelnut butter, marjoram in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweet-tart structure with vibrant acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Resonant, lingering flavor-saturated finish.

Coffee_Name: Kenya Washed Kiambu Gititu AB Top
Review_Description: Sweet-savory, richly layered, complex. Tamarind, tangerine zest, Nutella, black sage, myrrh in aroma and cup. Savory-sweet structure with citrusy acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Long, satisfying finish driven by tart fruit, citrus zest and dark chocolate impulses.
Blind Assessment: Sweet-savory, richly layered, complex. Tamarind, tangerine zest, Nutella, black sage, myrrh in aroma and cup. Savory-sweet structure with citrusy acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Long, satisfying finish driven by tart fruit, citrus zest and dark chocolate impulses.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of the Gititu Farmers’ Cooperative Society, from trees of the SL-28, SL-34 and Ruiru 11 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.

Review_Description: Balanced, floral- and fruit-driven. Dried cranberry, dark chocolate, almond butter, lilac, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with balanced, bright acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Cocoa- and floral-toned finish with undertones of hazelnut and Meyer lemon zest.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Sweetly tart structure with balanced, bright acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Cocoa- and floral-toned finish with undertones of hazelnut and Meyer lemon zest.
Notes: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are largely produced from distinctive indigenous Ethiopia landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Review_Description: Integrated, balanced, deep-toned. Raw chocolate, dried coconut, tiger lily, allspice, cedar in aroma and cup. Complex, sweet-savory structure with juicy-bright acidity; full, viscous mouthfeel. Sweetly rich finish, crisply chocolaty and spice-toned.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i

Notes: Produced by Armando and Karina Rodriguez of Aloha Star Farm, entirely of the Typica variety of Arabica. This is a blend of coffees from Typica variety trees processed by two different methods: traditional washed (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) and honey-processed (some fruit flesh is left on the bean during drying). Review_Description: Fruit-toned, sweetly tart. Strawberry guava, lemon balm, dark chocolate, tangerine zest, cane sugar in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with bright, juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Delicately fruity finish with undertones of strawberry and deep chocolate.
Coffee Origin: Ka‘ū growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i

Notes: A blend of coffees from Miranda Farms and JN Farms, from trees of the Red Catuai, Red Bourbon, Typica and Yellow Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by a proprietary method called “champagne natural,” in which fermentation using a wine yeast strain is applied to the whole fruit before it is dried. Review_Description: Floral, balanced, deep-toned. Star jasmine, Bing cherry, maple syrup, cocoa nib, bergamot in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with balanced, bright acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Cocoa-driven finish supported by bergamot and maple syrup.

Lin Jen-Wei’s Black Jar Coffee, a Taiwan-based nano-roaster and café, is named for both the Taiwanese slang phrase “black soy sauce in black jar,” indicating something is difficult to see through, and the literal black jar in which this company stores coffee to protect it from UV light. Review_Description: Deeply sweet-savory, yet bright and juicy. Dark chocolate, candycap mushroom, red currant, marjoram, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly savory structure with juicy, high-toned acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. The very long, very sweet finish is flavor-laden and rich.
Blind Assessment: Deeply sweet-savory, yet bright and juicy. Dark chocolate, candycap mushroom, red currant, marjoram, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly savory structure with juicy, high-toned acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. The very long, very sweet finish is flavor-laden and rich.

Review_Description: Deep-toned, bright and lively. Pomegranate, dark chocolate, pineapple saltwater taffy, almond butter, key lime in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with high-toned, balanced acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. The fruit-toned finish is complex and long, centered around notes of pineapple saltwater taffy, key lime and rich dark chocolate.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Review_Description: Delicately citrusy, multi-layered. Pink grapefruit zest, apricot, salted caramel, baking chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with bright, balanced acidity; energetic, satiny mouthfeel. The bright finish consolidates to notes of pink grapefruit zest and salted caramel.

Sweetly tart structure with bright, balanced acidity; energetic, satiny mouthfeel. The bright finish consolidates to notes of pink grapefruit zest and salted caramel.

Coffee_Name: Ecuador Legrand Robusta Lactic Natural Espresso
Review_Description: Evaluated as espresso. Gingko nut, artichoke liqueur, strawberry, pink peppercorn, nutmeg in aroma and small cup. Crisply creamy mouthfeel; bittersweet, gently fermenty finish. In three parts milk, savory-leaning (artichoke liqueur) and sweetly nut-toned.
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Gingko nut, artichoke liqueur, strawberry, pink peppercorn, nutmeg in aroma and small cup. Crisply creamy mouthfeel; bittersweet, gently fermenty finish. In three parts milk, savory-leaning (artichoke liqueur) and sweetly nut-toned.
Notes: Produced by Denise Bustamonte, entirely of the Robusta species, and processed by anaerobic natural method, in which whole fruit is fermented in tanks with limited oxygen before drying, also in the whole fruit. In this case, lactic acid was added to the fermentation step. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Bottom Line: A uniquely composed, experimentally processed Ecuador Robusta roasted for espresso: bittersweet, complex, intentionally fermenty, and delicately fruity and nutty.

Review_Description: Crisp, delicate. Dried green apple, caramel, pecan, orange zest, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with gentle acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. The quiet finish is balanced and friendly.
Blind Assessment: Crisp, delicate. Dried green apple, caramel, pecan, orange zest, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with gentle acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. The quiet finish is balanced and friendly.
