Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, chocolaty. Pomegranate, baking chocolate, orange zest, almond, oak in aroma and cup. Tart-leaning structure with brisk acidity; plush, chewy mouthfeel. Crisply chocolaty finish with undertones of pomegranate and almond.
Notes: Produced by Sergio Roldan, from trees of the Colombia, Caturra and Chiroso varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Mostra Coffee is a women-, minority-, veteran-, and immigrant-owned micro-roaster based in north county San Diego. For more information, visit www.mostracoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A crisp, fruit-centered natural Colombia with pleasing chocolate notes throughout the cup.

Review_Description: Gently tart, sweetly herbaceous. Orange zest, pomegranate, cocoa nib, goat milk yogurt, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with tangy acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The gently drying finish centers around notes of orange zest and cedar.
Blind Assessment: Gently tart, sweetly herbaceous. Orange zest, pomegranate, cocoa nib, goat milk yogurt, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with tangy acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The gently drying finish centers around notes of orange zest and cedar.
Notes: Produced by Kalsada Coffee from trees of the Typica, Bourbon and Garnica varieties of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before drying, also in the whole fruit. Mostra Coffee is a women-, minority-, veteran-, and immigrant-owned micro-roaster based in north county San Diego. For more information, visit www.mostracoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A uniquely composed anaerobic-fermented Philippines with tangy, yogurt-like notes and attractive cocoa undertones.

Coffee_Name: Philippines Sitio Kisbong #3011 Experimental Wine Yeast
Review_Description: Delicately fruit-forward. Goji berry, lime, cocoa powder, fresh-cut fir, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with gently acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet, aromatic wood-framed finish supported by notes of cocoa powder and lime.
Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-forward. Goji berry, lime, cocoa powder, fresh-cut fir, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with gently acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet, aromatic wood-framed finish supported by notes of cocoa powder and lime.
Notes: Produced by Kalsada Coffee from trees of the Typica, Bourbon and Garnica varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit), with the addition of cultured wine yeasts. Mostra Coffee is a women-, minority-, veteran-, and immigrant-owned micro-roaster based in north county San Diego. For more information, visit www.mostracoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A gently fruity, experimentally processed Philippines coffee with crisp cocoa, dark berry and bright citrus notes.

Review_Description: Sweetly tart, richly fruit-toned. Raspberry, Meyer lemon zest, dark chocolate, cedar, pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Tart-leaning structure with juicy acidity; very full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. The finish centers around dark chocolate and raspberry.
Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, richly fruit-toned. Raspberry, Meyer lemon zest, dark chocolate, cedar, pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Tart-leaning structure with juicy acidity; very full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. The finish centers around dark chocolate and raspberry.
Notes: Produced by William Morra entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Based in Phoenix, Arizona, Press Coffee roasts in small batches to ensure the highest quality and consistency, while sharing their knowledge and passion for coffee with customers. Visit www.presscoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A focused, intensely fruit-forward Costa Rica natural driven by berry and dark chocolate notes.

Review_Description: Brightly sweet, quite vibrant. Pink grapefruit, cocoa nib, apricot, bay leaf, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy acidity; very silky, lively mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and sweet grapefruit.
Coffee Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet, quite vibrant. Pink grapefruit, cocoa nib, apricot, bay leaf, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy acidity; very silky, lively mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of cocoa nib and sweet grapefruit.
Notes: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are produced largely from local, indigenous varieties of Arabica. Produced by smallholding farmers under the direction of Kata Muduga and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Founded in 2011 by Keith Hamrick and Jen Lovrak, Northbound Coffee Roasters is a family-owned and -operated roastery in Mount Shasta, California. Visit northboundcoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A high-toned, cocoa- and stone fruit-driven washed Ethiopia with a throughline of sweet citrus notes and undercurrents of woodsy herbs.

Review_Description: Deeply aromatic, fruit-centered. Dried black cherry, cocoa nib, narcissus, thyme, a hint of wine barrel in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with high-toned acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish leads with notes of cocoa nib and narcissus.
Blind Assessment: Deeply aromatic, fruit-centered. Dried black cherry, cocoa nib, narcissus, thyme, a hint of wine barrel in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with high-toned acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish leads with notes of cocoa nib and narcissus.
Notes: Produced by Jose Giraldo entirely of the Ethiopia-seed Wush Wush variety of Arabica, and processed by the washed carbonic maceration method, in which the coffee fruit is first pulped then fermented in CO2-infused tanks before drying. Based in Phoenix, Arizona, Press Coffee roasts in small batches to ensure the highest quality and consistency, while sharing their knowledge and passion for coffee with customers. Visit www.presscoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A headily aromatic Colombia-grown Wush Wush processed by carbonic maceration, yielding a balanced, deeply fruity cup.

Review_Description: Richly sweet, nut-toned. Fig Newton, almond nougat, marjoram, cedar, magnolia in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Crisply sweet, nutty finish.
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, nut-toned. Fig Newton, almond nougat, marjoram, cedar, magnolia in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Crisply sweet, nutty finish.
Notes: Produced by Osbaldo Perez Ramirez, from trees of the Caturra and Bourbon varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Certified USDA Organic. Founded in 2011 by Keith Hamrick and Jen Lovrak, Northbound Coffee Roasters is a family-owned and -operated roastery in Mount Shasta, California. Visit northboundcoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A classic Guatemala cup with a full, viscous mouthfeel and deeply sweet nut tones throughout.

Review_Description: Bright, balanced, juicy-sweet. Red plum, cocoa nib, blood orange, star jasmine, lemon verbena in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with vibrant acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is long, lingering and flavor-saturated.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Bright, balanced, juicy-sweet. Red plum, cocoa nib, blood orange, star jasmine, lemon verbena in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with vibrant acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is long, lingering and flavor-saturated.
Notes: SL28 and SL34 are varieties famous for producing the great classic coffees of Kenya. Hula Daddy is a boutique coffee producer with farms at the 1,400- and 2,500-foot levels of the Mount Hualalai volcano near the northern end of the Kona growing district, five minutes above the town of Kailua-Kona. This SL34 coffee was produced at the higher elevation Hula Daddy farm and processed anaerobically using commercial yeast. Visit www.huladaddy.com or call 808-327-9744 for more information.
Bottom Line: A Kona-Kenya mashup: This is an SL 34 variety grown in Kona that’s deep-toned and intricately balanced, with notes of stone fruit, cocoa nib and complex florals.

Coffee_Name: El Salvador 2022 COE#17 El Mirador Washed Gesha
Review_Description: Floral-toned, mult-layered, balanced. Narcissus, dark chocolate, pomegranate, frankincense, in aroma and small cup. Very syrupy-smooth mouthfeel; rich, harmonious, elongated finish. Exceptionally complex in three parts milk, where narcissus and dark chocolate notes commingle with pomegranate and frankincense.
Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, mult-layered, balanced. Narcissus, dark chocolate, pomegranate, frankincense, in aroma and small cup. Very syrupy-smooth mouthfeel; rich, harmonious, elongated finish. Exceptionally complex in three parts milk, where narcissus and dark chocolate notes commingle with pomegranate and frankincense.
Notes: Evaluated as espresso. Produced by Finca El Mirador, entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Bottom Line: A divinely floral-toned, chocolaty single-origin El Salvador espresso, delicately balanced between tart fruit and sweet floral impulses.

Coffee_Name: Panama ABU Washed Gesha Lot GW57
Review_Description: Lushly floral-toned. Vanilla orchid, ginger blossom, cocoa nib, pluot, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Elegantly sweet structure with juicy, balanced acidity; very syrupy mouthfeel. The long, resonant, flavor-laden finish carries over all the aroma and flavor notes from the cup.
Coffee Origin: Cañas Verdes, Boquete growing region, western Panama
Blind Assessment: Lushly floral-toned. Vanilla orchid, ginger blossom, cocoa nib, pluot, pink grapefruit zest in aroma and cup. Elegantly sweet structure with juicy, balanced acidity; very syrupy mouthfeel. The long, resonant, flavor-laden finish carries over all the aroma and flavor notes from the cup.
Notes: Produced by Josel Luttrell of Abu Coffee Plantations entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Bottom Line: A heady, floral Panama Gesha cup with top notes of vanilla and ginger supported by deep cocoa and gently spicy citrus zest.

Coffee_Name: Guatemala Natural El General Bistro Lot Espresso
Review_Description: Sweetly tart, fruit-driven and floral. Tangerine zest, tamarind, chocolate fudge, agave syrup, sandalwood in aroma and small cup. Plush, syrupy mouthfeel; chocolaty, tart-fruit finish. Bright, balanced and juicy in cappuccino-scaled milk.
Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, fruit-driven and floral. Tangerine zest, tamarind, chocolate fudge, agave syrup, sandalwood in aroma and small cup. Plush, syrupy mouthfeel; chocolaty, tart-fruit finish. Bright, balanced and juicy in cappuccino-scaled milk.
Notes: Evaluated as espresso. A blend of Catuai and Bourbon varieties of Arabica produced by Finca El General in Acatenango, Guatemala and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Bottom Line: A complex, richly bittersweet single-origin natural-process Guatemala espresso with deep chocolate and tart fruit notes and undertones of aromatic wood redolent of sandalwood.

Review_Description: Richly fruit-centered, deeply chocolaty. Dried mango, dark chocolate, wisteria, cedar, lemon thyme in aroma and cup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with winy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The deep-toned finish consolidates to notes of dried mango, dark chocolate and cedar.
Blind Assessment: Richly fruit-centered, deeply chocolaty. Dried mango, dark chocolate, wisteria, cedar, lemon thyme in aroma and cup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with winy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The deep-toned finish consolidates to notes of dried mango, dark chocolate and cedar.
Notes: Produced by Tadesse Teko Teero, entirely from the 74112 variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Bottom Line: A lively, enticing, deeply sweet and richly tart natural-processed Ethiopia with a dark chocolate throughline.

Review_Description: Chocolaty and sweetly nut-toned. Baking chocolate, date, freesia, almond, cedar in aroma and small cup. Plush, syrupy mouthfeel; crisply sweet finish with notes of baking chocolate and cedar. In three parts milk, deeply chocolaty with distinct almond notes.
Blind Assessment: Chocolaty and sweetly nut-toned. Baking chocolate, date, freesia, almond, cedar in aroma and small cup. Plush, syrupy mouthfeel; crisply sweet finish with notes of baking chocolate and cedar. In three parts milk, deeply chocolaty with distinct almond notes.
Notes: Evaluated as espresso. A blend of coffees from Guatemala, Brazil, Colombia and Ethiopia, roasted for espresso applications. MoonMoon Coffee is a Taiwan community coffee retailer and roaster that believes that “coffee is life, and we keep making the coffee better.” MoonMoon in mandarin means “friends.” For more information visit www.facebook.com/mu2coffee/.
Bottom Line: A solid espresso blend comprised of coffees from four origins — Guatemala, Brazil, Colombia and Ethiopia — with notes of baking chocolate and spice-toned florals.

Review_Description: Brightly sweet-tart, fruit-toned. Apricot, dark chocolate, pistachio butter, bay leaf, blood orange in aroma and cup. High-toned and sweet with juicy acidity; viscous, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Resonant, flavor-laden finish consolidates to dark chocolate and pistachio notes.
Coffee Origin: Arbegona, Sidamo growing region, south-central Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet-tart, fruit-toned. Apricot, dark chocolate, pistachio butter, bay leaf, blood orange in aroma and cup. High-toned and sweet with juicy acidity; viscous, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Resonant, flavor-laden finish consolidates to dark chocolate and pistachio notes.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, from trees of local heirloom varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Bottom Line: A nuanced, fruit-driven washed Ethiopia cup that’s deep, complex and juicy-sweet.

Review_Description: Deep-toned, richly chocolaty. Dark chocolate, Fig Newton, magnolia, dried cherry, cedar in aroma and small cup. Satiny-smooth mouthfeel; chocolaty and floral-toned finish. In three parts milk, dark chocolate is foregrounded, with support from dried cherry and cedar notes.
Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, richly chocolaty. Dark chocolate, Fig Newton, magnolia, dried cherry, cedar in aroma and small cup. Satiny-smooth mouthfeel; chocolaty and floral-toned finish. In three parts milk, dark chocolate is foregrounded, with support from dried cherry and cedar notes.

Bottom Line: A deeply chocolaty and sweetly floral espresso, especially appealing in cappuccino format.

Coffee_Name: Colombia Finca Luisa Juan Pablo Carbonic Maceration
Review_Description: Fruit-toned, crisply cocoa-driven. Tropical fruit melange, cocoa powder, gardenia, balsa wood, cashew in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Sweet, wood-framed finish with quiet fruit notes.
Blind Assessment: Fruit-toned, crisply cocoa-driven. Tropical fruit melange, cocoa powder, gardenia, balsa wood, cashew in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; lightly satiny mouthfeel. Sweet, wood-framed finish with quiet fruit notes.
Notes: Produced by Juan Pablo of Finca La Luisa, from trees of the Yellow and Red Caturra varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural carbonic maceration method, which involves fermenting whole coffee fruit inside a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2, then drying the coffee in the whole fruit. Review_Description: Crisp, citrusy-sweet. Baking chocolate, lime zest, cedar, date, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; silky mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and lime zest.
Coffee Origin: Shakiso District, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Review_Description: Juicy-bright, multi-layered. Red currant, salted caramel, blood orange, star jasmine, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with richly vibrant, balanced acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The complexity of the cup carries through in the long, juicy finish.
Blind Assessment: Juicy-bright, multi-layered. Red currant, salted caramel, blood orange, star jasmine, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with richly vibrant, balanced acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The complexity of the cup carries through in the long, juicy finish.

Review_Description: Crisply sweet-tart. Cocoa powder, lavender, golden raisin, agave syrup, lime zest in aroma and cup. Richly bittersweet structure with brisk acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Delicate, chocolaty finish with lavender undertones.
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-tart. Cocoa powder, lavender, golden raisin, agave syrup, lime zest in aroma and cup. Richly bittersweet structure with brisk acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Delicate, chocolaty finish with lavender undertones.

Review_Description: Vibrantly floral- and fruit-forward. Narcissus, Concord grape, dark chocolate, sandalwood, blood orange in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with winey acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Focused finish led by Concord grape and darl chocolate notes, supported by sandalwood.
Blind Assessment: Vibrantly floral- and fruit-forward. Narcissus, Concord grape, dark chocolate, sandalwood, blood orange in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with winey acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. Focused finish led by Concord grape and darl chocolate notes, supported by sandalwood.
Notes: Produced by Rigoberto Herrera of Granja La Esperanza, entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by a hybrid washed method in which the coffee cherries are fermented whole for 48 hours in anaerobic tanks, then de-pulped and fermented again for another 96 hours. Following the second fermentation, the coffee is dried mechanically for 72 hours. Nostalgia Coffee Roasters is a woman-owned specialty coffee roaster founded by Taylor Fields in 2018 as a mobile café. Review_Description: Richly aromatic, floral-toned. Magnolia, cocoa nib, cane sugar, red plum, nutmeg in aroma and cup. Elegantly sweet structure with delicate, bright acidity; silky, vibrant mouthfeel. Flavor-saturated finish centered around notes of magnolia and cocoa nib, complicated by undertones of nutmeg.

Flavor-saturated finish centered around notes of magnolia and cocoa nib, complicated by undertones of nutmeg.

Review_Description: Balanced, deeply chocolaty. Dark chocolate, orange zest, plum, almond, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; full, satiny mouthfeel. Chocolaty, nut-toned finish with undertones of marjoram.

Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). Review_Description: Richly spice-toned, citrusy-sweet. Ginger blossom, dried persimmon, Concord grape, rice candy, a hint of fennel in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy, vibrant acidity; lushly vibrant, creamy mouthfeel. The finish quiets to pretty notes of ginger and persimmon.
Blind Assessment: Richly spice-toned, citrusy-sweet. Ginger blossom, dried persimmon, Concord grape, rice candy, a hint of fennel in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy, vibrant acidity; lushly vibrant, creamy mouthfeel. The finish quiets to pretty notes of ginger and persimmon.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez entirely of the Orange Bourbon variety of Arabica. Processed by a complex double fermentation method, in which ​​the coffee fruit is first sterilized, then fermented anaerobically in the whole fruit in a bio-reactor with added microorganisms. After this fermentation in the whole fruit, the coffee is pulped and subjected to a second fermentation, after which the beans are sealed through the impact of hot and cold water before washing and careful drying by machine for 36 hours. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Review_Description: Delicate, richly aromatic. Lychee, saffron, blood orange, almond, cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with vibrant acidity; crisp, silky-smooth mouthfeel. The resonant finish centers around lychee and cocoa nib.
Coffee Origin: Odo Shakiso District, Guji Zone, southern Ethiopia

Review_Description: Richly chocolaty, deeply sweet. Dark chocolate, almond butter, peach, cedar, magnolia in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with balanced acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolaty and nut-toned finish.

Sweet-toned structure with brisk, savory acidity; crisp, velvety-smooth mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of cane sugar and lily in the short, with tangerine notes resurfacing in the long.

Review_Description: Balanced, deeply sweet-savory. Red currant, maple syrup, almond brittle, lime zest, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with savory acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Sweet, inviting finish with notes of maple syrup and almond brittle.

Review_Description: Brightly sweet, delicately spice-toned. Apricot, nutmeg, freesia-like flowers, hazelnut, baking chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with lively acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Apricot and hazelnut lead in the gentle finish.
Blind Assessment: Brightly sweet, delicately spice-toned. Apricot, nutmeg, freesia-like flowers, hazelnut, baking chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with lively acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Apricot and hazelnut lead in the gentle finish.
Notes: Produced by Manuel Alberto Romero Sánchez of Finca Indera entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the honey method, in which skins are removed but some of the fruit flesh (“honey”) is allowed to adhere to the beans during drying. Diastaticus. (Strains from this yeast variety are commonly used in producing Saison style beers.) After this fermentation in the whole fruit, the coffee is pulped and subjected to a second fermentation phase, after which the beans are sealed through the impact of hot and cold water before drying by machine for 46 hours at 38C (100F). Review_Description: Complex, multi-layered. Black cherry, candy cap mushroom, tangerine zest, sandalwood, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with richly bright acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The long finish centers around notes of black cherry and candy cap mushroom.

Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory. White peach, hop flowers, cocoa powder, pineapple kefir, fir in aroma and cup. Sweetly savory structure with brisk acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of cocoa powder and fir.
Notes: Produced by Benjamin Weiner at Finca Idealista entirely of the Yellow Pacamara variety of Arabica, and processed by the carbonic maceration method, which involves fermenting whole coffee fruit inside a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2, then drying the coffee, still in the whole fruit. Established in Cleveland, Ohio in 2014, Eccentricity Coffee Co. roasts small-batch coffees that highlight each coffee’s full potential. Visit www.eccentricitycoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A carbonic-macerated Yellow Pacamara grown in Nicaragua that’s equal parts sweet (stone fruit and cocoa) and savory (hops and aromatic wood).

Review_Description: Chocolaty, sweetly tart. Blueberry, molasses, lemon, cocoa powder, allspice in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; crisply smooth, velvety mouthfeel. Allspice and baking chocolate lead in the crisp finish.
Blind Assessment: Chocolaty, sweetly tart. Blueberry, molasses, lemon, cocoa powder, allspice in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; crisply smooth, velvety mouthfeel. Allspice and baking chocolate lead in the crisp finish.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Brazil, Guatemala, Tanzania and Ethiopia. Honta Coffee is a Taiwan-based specialty roaster. Visit www.honta.tw/phone/index.html for more information.
Bottom Line: A berry- and chocolate-toned blend — clean, delicately fruit-forward, richly sweet.

Review_Description: Crisply sweet, cocoa-toned. Baking chocolate, orange zest, tamarind, cedar, lily in aroma and cup. Sweet in structure with low-toned, gentle acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The gently drying finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and lily with cedar undertones.
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, cocoa-toned. Baking chocolate, orange zest, tamarind, cedar, lily in aroma and cup. Sweet in structure with low-toned, gentle acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The gently drying finish consolidates to notes of baking chocolate and lily with cedar undertones.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Brazil, Guatemala and Colombia. Honta Coffee is a Taiwan-based specialty roaster. Visit www.honta.tw/phone/index.html for more information.
Bottom Line: A friendly, accessible cocoa-driven blend with sweet floral and citrus tones throughout the profile.

Review_Description: Delicate, multi-layered. Narcissus, bergamot, cocoa nib, cedar, marjoram in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with bright, balanced acidity; plush, silky mouthfeel. Floral finish with ballast from cocoa nib.
Blind Assessment: Delicate, multi-layered. Narcissus, bergamot, cocoa nib, cedar, marjoram in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with bright, balanced acidity; plush, silky mouthfeel. Floral finish with ballast from cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers surrounding the Keramo Daye Bensa Washing Station owned by brothers Asefa and Mulugeta Dukamo from the 74110 and 74158 varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Founded in Savannah Georgia, PERC Coffee Roasters has a total of three cafes in Savannah and Atlanta, as well as a coffee education and training center. Visit www.perccoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: Elegant and powerful, this floral-toned natural-processed Ethiopia is complex and deep, with the flowers supported by sweet fruit and deep-toned cocoa.

Review_Description: Richly chocolaty, balanced and deep. Dark chocolate, date, magnolia, cane sugar, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with brisk acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The crisply sweet finish centers around notes of dark chocolate and magnolia.
Blind Assessment: Richly chocolaty, balanced and deep. Dark chocolate, date, magnolia, cane sugar, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with brisk acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The crisply sweet finish centers around notes of dark chocolate and magnolia.
Notes: Burundi is a small, landlocked country in the Great Lakes region of Central Africa. Most coffee is grown in the mountains of the north, bordering Rwanda. Benefiting from ideal growing conditions and large plantings of local strains of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica, Burundi coffee has an excellent reputation, though it is better known in Europe than in the United States. This is a wet-processed or “washed” coffee, meaning the fruit skin and pulp were removed from the beans immediately after harvesting and before drying. Mystic Monk Coffee is a small-batch roaster associated with a Carmelite monastery located in the Rocky Mountains of northern Wyoming. The monks emphasize an artisan approach to roasting and a commitment to quality. Visit www.mysticmonkcoffee.com or call 877-751-6377 for more information.
Bottom Line: A deep-toned, balanced, inviting Burundi — chocolaty and sweet, with undertones of magnolia and rich aromatic wood.

Review_Description: High-toned, citrusy. Mandarin orange, cocoa nib, aged grappa, brown sugar, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet-tart structure with vibrant acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish with notes of mandarin orange and brown sugar.
Blind Assessment: High-toned, citrusy. Mandarin orange, cocoa nib, aged grappa, brown sugar, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet-tart structure with vibrant acidity; crisp, lightly satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish with notes of mandarin orange and brown sugar.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers around the Kibingo Washing Station entirely of the Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by a version of the natural method in which the whole fruit is inoculated with cultured yeast and fermented. Founded in Savannah Georgia, PERC Coffee Roasters has a total of three cafes in Savannah and Atlanta, as well as a coffee education and training center. Visit www.perccoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A juicy, citrus-driven Burundi hybrid natural with undertones of rich sandalwood and a hint of sweet ferment.

Review_Description: Crisply sweet-savory. Fresh-cut oak, pie cherry, thyme, maple syrup, hop flowers in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with bittersweet acidity; very full, viscous mouthfeel. Crisp, richly wood-framed finish.
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory. Fresh-cut oak, pie cherry, thyme, maple syrup, hop flowers in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with bittersweet acidity; very full, viscous mouthfeel. Crisp, richly wood-framed finish.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers in the Aceh region of Sumatra from trees of the Ateng, Bor Bor, Catimor and Timor varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Founded in Savannah Georgia, PERC Coffee Roasters has a total of three cafes in Savannah and Atlanta, as well as a coffee education and training center. Visit www.perccoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: Given its essential sweet-savory structure, an especially bright Sumatra cup, citrusy and nimble, with a throughline of rich aromatic wood notes.

Review_Description: Complex, deeply engaging. Bing cherry, pomelo, salted caramel, lemon balm, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet-tart with vivacious acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The resonant finish consolidates around notes of cherry and bittersweet citrus.
Blind Assessment: Complex, deeply engaging. Bing cherry, pomelo, salted caramel, lemon balm, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet-tart with vivacious acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The resonant finish consolidates around notes of cherry and bittersweet citrus.
Notes: Despite grower discontent, unclear government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Bottom Line: A classic Kenya with notes of high-toned stone fruit, savory sweetness, citrus and rich aromatic wood.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia COE #8 Sidama Arbegona Muluneh Tute Galcho 74158 Natural
Review_Description: Delicately fruit-toned, richly sweet. Dried peach, narcissus, almond butter, marjoram, honey in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet with juicy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The harmonious finish carries forward all the notes from the aroma and cup.
Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-toned, richly sweet. Dried peach, narcissus, almond butter, marjoram, honey in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet with juicy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The harmonious finish carries forward all the notes from the aroma and cup.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers, entirely of the indigenous Ethiopian 74158 variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Small Eyes Café is a small, family-owned coffee shop in Yilan, Taiwan, specializing in artisanally roasted specialty coffee and homemade desserts. Visit www.facebook.com/Smalleyescafe for more information.
Bottom Line: A deep-toned, fruit- and floral-driven natural-processed Ethiopia cup with leading notes of stone fruit and spicy florals.

Review_Description: Delicately fruit-toned, crisply sweet. Strawberry, cocoa nib, lemon verbena, hazelnut, freesia-like flowers in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with gently bright acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Cocoa and almond dominate the finish with undertones of strawberry.
Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-toned, crisply sweet. Strawberry, cocoa nib, lemon verbena, hazelnut, freesia-like flowers in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with gently bright acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Cocoa and almond dominate the finish with undertones of strawberry.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees largely from indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This example is processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed before drying). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Bottom Line: A pretty, delicately confident washed Ethiopia cup with berry and sweet herb tones in the foreground.

Review_Description: Deep-toned, richly sweet. Black cherry, hazelnut, magnolia, cane sugar, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with winey acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of black cherry, hazelnut and tangerine zest.
Blind Assessment: Deep-toned, richly sweet. Black cherry, hazelnut, magnolia, cane sugar, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with winey acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The finish centers around notes of black cherry, hazelnut and tangerine zest.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers from trees of the Bourbon and Typica varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed from the beans before they are dried). JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Bottom Line: A balanced, harmoniously integrated Mexico coffee with rich, deep aromas that fulfill their promise in the cup.

Coffee_Name: Colombia Nariño Lucido Diaz Pink Bourbon
Review_Description: High-toned, richly sweet. Yellow plum, almond, cocoa nib, lilac, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The crisply sweet-tart finish centers around notes of plum and almond.
Blind Assessment: High-toned, richly sweet. Yellow plum, almond, cocoa nib, lilac, cedar in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The crisply sweet-tart finish centers around notes of plum and almond.
Notes: Produced by Lucido Diaz entirely of the admired Pink Bourbon variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and flesh are removed before drying). Founded in 1994, Coffee By Design is a specialty coffee roaster in Portland, Maine that also operates three coffee shops in town, as well as one in Freeport. Visit www.coffeebydesign.com.
Bottom Line: A balanced, harmonious Colombia Pink Bourbon with notes of stone fruit and almond as throughlines, supported by sweet florals.

Review_Description: Evaluated as espresso. Richly nut-toned. Cashew butter, magnolia, pear, baking chocolate, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Creamy mouthfeel; crisp, nutty finish. In three parts milk, both baking chocolate and cashew notes are amplified, while pear and magnolia remain undertones.
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly nut-toned. Cashew butter, magnolia, pear, baking chocolate, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Creamy mouthfeel; crisp, nutty finish. In three parts milk, both baking chocolate and cashew notes are amplified, while pear and magnolia remain undertones.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Brazil and Colombia, roasted for espresso applications. Small Eyes Café is a small, family-owned coffee shop in Yilan, Taiwan, specializing in artisanally roasted specialty coffee and homemade desserts. Visit https://www.facebook.com/Smalleyescafe for more information.
Bottom Line: A sweetly nutty and crisply chocolaty espresso blend of fine Colombia and Brazil coffees.

Review_Description: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly tart, richly chocolaty. Dark chocolate, orange zest, dried green apple, cedar, molasses in aroma and small cup. Richly drying mouthfeel; tart-leaning finish. Roundly sweet in three parts milk, which amplifies the molasses and chocolate notes.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly tart, richly chocolaty. Dark chocolate, orange zest, dried green apple, cedar, molasses in aroma and small cup. Richly drying mouthfeel; tart-leaning finish. Roundly sweet in three parts milk, which amplifies the molasses and chocolate notes.
Notes: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are largely produced from indigenous Ethiopian landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. New Life Enterprises is a Hong Kong-based NGO established in 1965 that oversees more than 20 social enterprises. Its coffee brand, cafe330, is designed to serve coffee lovers and provide food and beverage training for people recovering from mental illness. Visit www.nlpra.org.hk for more information.
Bottom Line: Tart and chocolaty in the straight shot; more brightly chocolaty and fruit-toned in cappuccino-scaled milk.

Coffee_Name: Finca El Guarumal El Salvador Black Honey
Review_Description: Fruit-toned, gently fermenty. Dried apricot, wine barrel, dark chocolate, brown sugar, gardenia in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with winy acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish with notes of sweet wine-like ferment.
Blind Assessment: Fruit-toned, gently fermenty. Dried apricot, wine barrel, dark chocolate, brown sugar, gardenia in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with winy acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish with notes of sweet wine-like ferment.
Notes: Produced by Fernando Alfaro and Jose Enrique Gutierrez at Finca El Guarumal from trees of the Yellow Caturra and Red Caturra varieties of Arabica and processed by the black honey method, in which the skins are removed from the fruit but virtually all of the fruit flesh is allowed to dry slowly on the beans, often resulting in a deep, pungent profile. New Life Enterprises is a Hong Kong-based NGO established in 1965 that oversees more than 20 social enterprises. Its coffee brand, cafe330, is designed to serve coffee lovers and provide food and beverage training for people recovering from mental illness. Visit www.nlpra.org.hk for more information.
Bottom Line: A gently winy El Salvador cup, fruit-forward yet crisp and chocolaty.

Review_Description: Floral-toned, richly sweet, balanced. Narcissus, dark chocolate, red plum, almond brittle, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. The crisply sweet finish leads with notes of plum and chocolate with cedar undertones.
Blind Assessment: Floral-toned, richly sweet, balanced. Narcissus, dark chocolate, red plum, almond brittle, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with brisk acidity; very full, syrupy mouthfeel. The crisply sweet finish leads with notes of plum and chocolate with cedar undertones.
Notes: Produced at Granja Paraiso entirely of the Colombia variety of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method with Saccromyces Pastorianus yeast added during the ferment step. Decaffeinated at origin in Colombia using ethyl acetate, an organic compound derived from sugar cane. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Bottom Line: An extraordinary decaf coffee — richly floral, crisply chocolaty, with high-toned stone fruit notes throughout.

Review_Description: Crisply sweet, fruit-toned. Dried blueberry, baking chocolate, lily, fresh-cut fir, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; smooth, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of dried blueberry and fresh-cut fir with baking chocolate undertones.
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, fruit-toned. Dried blueberry, baking chocolate, lily, fresh-cut fir, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with brisk acidity; smooth, satiny mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of dried blueberry and fresh-cut fir with baking chocolate undertones.
Notes: Produced by Rigoberto Herrera at Granja La Esperanza from trees of the Castillio, Caturra and Colombia varieties of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Small Batch Coffee is a specialty roaster with five cafes and a coffee cart in various Brighton, England neighborhoods. Visit www.smallbatchcoffee.co.uk for more information.
Bottom Line: A crisply fruity natural-processed Colombia cup nicely complicated by a dry chocolate.

Coffee_Name: Philippines Sitio San Roque Robusta Anaerobic Natural
Review_Description: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply chocolaty, sweetly nutty. Baking chocolate, hazelnut butter, black cherry, cedar, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Crisply satiny mouthfeel; gently drying, nutty finish. In three parts milk, chocolate notes bloom and commingle with sweet hazelnut.
Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply chocolaty, sweetly nutty. Baking chocolate, hazelnut butter, black cherry, cedar, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Crisply satiny mouthfeel; gently drying, nutty finish. In three parts milk, chocolate notes bloom and commingle with sweet hazelnut.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers near the Kalsada Sitio San Roque mill entirely of the Robusta species, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before drying, still in the whole fruit. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Bottom Line: An impressive Robusta espresso from The Philippines: chocolaty, sweetly nutty, and complex; especially appealing in cappuccino format.

Review_Description: Elegantly fruit-toned, crisp and bright. Strawberry guava, cocoa nib, lilac, pistachio, lemon thyme in aroma and cup. Richly sweet-tart structure with juicy acidity; viscous, satiny mouthfeel. Berry-toned finish supported by cocoa nib.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing region, Big Island of Hawai’i
Blind Assessment: Elegantly fruit-toned, crisp and bright. Strawberry guava, cocoa nib, lilac, pistachio, lemon thyme in aroma and cup. Richly sweet-tart structure with juicy acidity; viscous, satiny mouthfeel. Berry-toned finish supported by cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers and processed by the washed method with the addition of cultured yeasts during the fermentation step. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Bottom Line: A washed-process Ka'u coffee with the addition of wine yeasts to the ferment step. Delicate, confident, fruity and complex.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia Gesha Village Illubabor Forest Lot 22/043 (Single-Terroir) Natural Process
Review_Description: Elegantly sweet, fruit- and floral toned. Dried Bing cherry, star jasmine, cocoa nib, sandalwood, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy, bright acidity; crisp, silky mouthfeel. Resounding and very long finish centered around notes of Bing cherry, cocoa nib, and star jasmine.
Blind Assessment: Elegantly sweet, fruit- and floral toned. Dried Bing cherry, star jasmine, cocoa nib, sandalwood, marjoram in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy, bright acidity; crisp, silky mouthfeel. Resounding and very long finish centered around notes of Bing cherry, cocoa nib, and star jasmine.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also Geisha) by Adam and Rachel Overton. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. Although the Gesha variety originated in Ethiopia, it was “discovered” by the coffee world in 2004 growing in Boquete, Panama, and Panama continues to dominate the expanding world of Gesha. This particular version, however, is the outcome of efforts to commercialize Gesha in the region from which it originally came. It was processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit www.buoncaffe.com.tw for more information.
Bottom Line: A sophisticated, nuanced natural-processed Ethiopia Gesha centered around notes of dried stonefruit, cocoa nib and sweet herbs.

Review_Description: Delicately aromatic, complex. Lilac, cocoa nib, pink grapefruit zest, shishito pepper, apricot in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with juicy, bright acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Floral finish with cocoa undertones.
Coffee Origin: Agaro Gera, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia
Blind Assessment: Delicately aromatic, complex. Lilac, cocoa nib, pink grapefruit zest, shishito pepper, apricot in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with juicy, bright acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Floral finish with cocoa undertones.
Notes: Ethiopia coffees like this one are largely produced largely from traditional indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica. Produced by smallholding members of the Nano Challa Cooperative and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Mostra Coffee is a women-, minority-, veteran-, and immigrant-owned micro-roaster based in north county San Diego. For more information, visit www.mostracoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A nuanced, multilayered washed Ethiopia cup with spicy floral notes at its center and a throughline of cocoa nib.

Review_Description: Sweetly spiced-toned, chocolaty. Dried plum, maple syrup, pink peppercorn, dark chocolate, star jasmine in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with high-toned acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The especially long, resounding finish carries over all the flavor notes from the cup.
Blind Assessment: Sweetly spiced-toned, chocolaty. Dried plum, maple syrup, pink peppercorn, dark chocolate, star jasmine in aroma and cup. Sweet-savory structure with high-toned acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The especially long, resounding finish carries over all the flavor notes from the cup.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers around the Ichamama Factory or mill, and processed by the traditional Kenya washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Mostra Coffee is a women-, minority-, veteran-, and immigrant-owned micro-roaster based in north county San Diego. For more information, visit www.mostracoffee.com.
Bottom Line: An evocative Kenya cup redolent of rich floral and sweet spice tones, with an especially resonant finish.

Coffee_Name: Panama Hartmann Estate Chicho Gallo Amaro Gayo Natural BOP#1
Review_Description: Complex, sweetly tart, spice-toned. Plum, fine musk, toffee, macadamia nut, dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with vibrant, juicy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The crisp finish centers around notes of plum and dark chocolate.
Blind Assessment: Complex, sweetly tart, spice-toned. Plum, fine musk, toffee, macadamia nut, dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with vibrant, juicy acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The crisp finish centers around notes of plum and dark chocolate.
Notes: Produced by the Hartmann family of Finca Hartmann, entirely of the Amaro Gayo (Ethiopian landrace) variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit www.buoncaffe.com.tw for more information.
Bottom Line: A complex natural-processed Panama cup redolent of stone fruit, sweet nut and musky florals, enlivened by a bright, vibrant acidity.

Review_Description: Richly sweet, deeply savory. Wisteria, red currant, tangerine zest, tamarind, cedar in aroma and cup. Balanced structure with vibrant acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The finish leads with wisteria and red currant.
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, deeply savory. Wisteria, red currant, tangerine zest, tamarind, cedar in aroma and cup. Balanced structure with vibrant acidity; full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The finish leads with wisteria and red currant.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers around the Ichamama Factory or mill, and processed by the traditional Kenya washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Mostra Coffee is a women-, minority-, veteran-, and immigrant-owned micro-roaster based in north county San Diego. For more information, visit www.mostracoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A floral-driven Kenya cup supported by a brightly sweet-savory structure.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia Guji Hamela Buku Abel Washed Process
Review_Description: Complex, delicate, sweetly tart. Star jasmine, pink grapefruit zest, white peach, cedar, bay leaf in aroma and cup. Crisp, sweetly tart structure with bright acidity; silky-smooth mouthfeel. Grapefruit, white peach and cedar notes lead in the layered finish.
Blind Assessment: Complex, delicate, sweetly tart. Star jasmine, pink grapefruit zest, white peach, cedar, bay leaf in aroma and cup. Crisp, sweetly tart structure with bright acidity; silky-smooth mouthfeel. Grapefruit, white peach and cedar notes lead in the layered finish.
Notes: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are produced largely from traditional Ethiopian landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp removed before drying). Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit www.buoncaffe.com.tw for more information.
Bottom Line: A classic representation of the washed southern Ethiopia type, citrusy and floral with rich aromatics throughout.

Review_Description: Richly sweet, cocoa-toned. Dark chocolate, dried apricot, hazelnut, freesia-like flowers, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweet structure with high-toned acidity; satiny-smooth mouthfeel. The finish is crisply chocolaty with undertones of dried apricot and hazelnut.
Blind Assessment: Richly sweet, cocoa-toned. Dark chocolate, dried apricot, hazelnut, freesia-like flowers, maple syrup in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweet structure with high-toned acidity; satiny-smooth mouthfeel. The finish is crisply chocolaty with undertones of dried apricot and hazelnut.
Notes: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are largely produced from distinctive indigenous Ethiopian landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in their respective regions. This is a dry-processed or “natural” version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. Buon Caffe is a specialty coffee roaster and cafe in Taipei, Taiwan. Visit www.buoncaffe.com.tw for more information.
Bottom Line: A balanced, inviting natural-processed Ethiopia with leading notes of cocoa-toned fruit and spice-toned florals.

Review_Description: Elegantly bright, very balanced. Apricot, honeysuckle, almond brittle, dark chocolate, cedar in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with floral acidity; lively, silky mouthfeel. Long, lingering, complexly satiating finish.
Blind Assessment: Elegantly bright, very balanced. Apricot, honeysuckle, almond brittle, dark chocolate, cedar in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with floral acidity; lively, silky mouthfeel. Long, lingering, complexly satiating finish.
Notes: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are largely produced from traditional Ethiopian landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Processed by the washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit redroostercoffee.com or call 540-745-7338 for more information.
Bottom Line: A classic washed Ethiopia cup that foregrounds stone fruit, complex flowers and seductive chocolate notes.

Review_Description: Richly floral-toned, vibrant. Star jasmine, wild strawberry, honey, dark chocolate, mustard seed in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with delicately juicy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The flavor-saturated finish carries over all the notes from the cup.
Blind Assessment: Richly floral-toned, vibrant. Star jasmine, wild strawberry, honey, dark chocolate, mustard seed in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with delicately juicy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The flavor-saturated finish carries over all the notes from the cup.
Notes: Nekisse is a proprietary brand of Ethiopia coffee developed by Ninety Plus, a distinguished boutique developer and importer of innovative small-lot coffees from Ethiopia and Panama. Grown near Neji in the Sidama/Sidamo growing region, this is a dry-processed or “natural” coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. BEI Coffee Roasters is a Hong Kong-based specialty roaster focused on microlots and multiple roasting methods for the same coffee. Visit www.facebook.com/bei.coffeekan.
Bottom Line: A beautifully structured, harmoniously integrated natural-processed Ethiopia cup — elegantly bright, fruity, floral, chocolaty.

Coffee_Name: Colombia Finca Samboni Gesha Anaerobic Natural
Review_Description: High-toned, fruit-driven. Raspberry jam, cocoa nib, Meyer lemon zest, narcissus, a hint of oregano in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with bright, juicy acidity; round, plush mouthfeel. The confident finish centers around notes of raspberry and cocoa nib.
Blind Assessment: High-toned, fruit-driven. Raspberry jam, cocoa nib, Meyer lemon zest, narcissus, a hint of oregano in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with bright, juicy acidity; round, plush mouthfeel. The confident finish centers around notes of raspberry and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by John Samboni of Finca Samboni entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, wherein whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before drying. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious, high-quality coffee. Visit redroostercoffee.com or call 540-745-7338 for more information.
Bottom Line: A cleanly fruit-forward Colombia Gesha cup processed by the anaerobic natural method, which highlights sweet fruit and spicy floral tones.

Review_Description: Crisply sweet-savory, rich-toned. Cocoa nib, grape candy, hop flowers, amber, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with sparkling acidity; viscous, very full mouthfeel. A crisply sweet-savory finish consolidates to notes of amber and cocoa nib.
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-savory, rich-toned. Cocoa nib, grape candy, hop flowers, amber, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with sparkling acidity; viscous, very full mouthfeel. A crisply sweet-savory finish consolidates to notes of amber and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by Joseph Brodsky at Ninety Plus Candela Estates entirely of the Gesha variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method (whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before drying, still in the whole fruit). BEI Coffee Roasters is a Hong Kong-based specialty roaster focused on microlots and multiple roasting methods for the same coffee. Visit www.facebook.com/bei.coffeekan.
Bottom Line: A strikingly structured anaerobic natural Panama cup that’s distinctly savory with sweet candy-like undertones.

Review_Description: Sweetly nutty, crisply chocolaty. Cashew butter, baking chocolate, date, maple syrup, magnolia in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with brisk acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of cashew and maple syrup.
Coffee Origin: Sul de Minas, Cerrado Mineiro, Mogiana, and Matas de Minas growing regions, Brazil
Blind Assessment: Sweetly nutty, crisply chocolaty. Cashew butter, baking chocolate, date, maple syrup, magnolia in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with brisk acidity; full, creamy mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of cashew and maple syrup.
Notes: A blend of Santos #2-grade coffees from a mixture of local varieties of Arabica,  processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). BEI Coffee Roasters is a Hong Kong-based specialty roaster focused on microlots and multiple roasting methods for the same coffee. Visit https://www.facebook.com/bei.coffeekan.
Bottom Line: A sweet, chocolate- and nut-toned natural-processed Brazil cup with an especially creamy body.

Review_Description: Quietly sweet, nut-toned. Hazelnut, cocoa powder, golden raisin, cedar, a hint of gardenia in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with gentle, round acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The crisply sweet finish leads with notes of cocoa powder and hazelnut.
Coffee Origin: Sul de Minas, Cerrado Mineiro, Mogiana, and Matas de Minas growing regions, Brazil
Blind Assessment: Quietly sweet, nut-toned. Hazelnut, cocoa powder, golden raisin, cedar, a hint of gardenia in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with gentle, round acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The crisply sweet finish leads with notes of cocoa powder and hazelnut.
Notes: A blend of Santos #2-grade coffees from a mixture of local varieties of Arabica,  processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). BEI Coffee Roasters is a Hong Kong-based specialty roaster focused on microlots and multiple roasting methods for the same coffee. Visit https://www.facebook.com/bei.coffeekan.
Bottom Line: A friendly, sweetly nutty natural-processed Brazil cup.

Review_Description: Elegantly fruit-forward, delicately juicy. Strawberry guava, malted milk balls, freesia-like flowers, pink peppercorn, marjoram in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweet-tart structure with gently bright acidity; plump, satiny mouthfeel. Crisp, sweet finish centered on suggestions of freesia and pink peppercorn.
Blind Assessment: Elegantly fruit-forward, delicately juicy. Strawberry guava, malted milk balls, freesia-like flowers, pink peppercorn, marjoram in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweet-tart structure with gently bright acidity; plump, satiny mouthfeel. Crisp, sweet finish centered on suggestions of freesia and pink peppercorn.
Notes: Produced by José Giraldo and Jorge Correa of Finca San Juan entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural carbonic maceration method, which involves fermenting whole coffee fruit inside a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2, then drying the coffee, still in the whole fruit. Founded in 1990, Roadmap CoffeeWorks, formerly Lexington Coffee Roasters, is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Lexington, Virginia. Roadmap CoffeeWorks focuses on producing fresh, distinctive and sustainable coffees. Visit www.roadmapcoffeeworks.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Bottom Line: A deep, subtly invigorating carbonic-macerated Colombia Geisha cup with notes of tropical fruit and spicy flowers, complicated by a sweet herbaceousness.

Coffee_Name: Ethiopia BergWu Maker Series Yirgacheffe Wuri G1 Lot MW21/02
Review_Description: High-toned, richly bittersweet. Bergamot, lychee, star jasmine, cocoa nib, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with juicy-bright acidity; very full, satinly mouthfeel. Crisp, tart finish with notes of lychee and cocoa nib.
Blind Assessment: High-toned, richly bittersweet. Bergamot, lychee, star jasmine, cocoa nib, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart with juicy-bright acidity; very full, satinly mouthfeel. Crisp, tart finish with notes of lychee and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers from selections of indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Angeles Roastery is a Hong Kong-based coffee Roastery established in 2021. Visit www.angelesroastery.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A classic washed Ethiopia cup profile: bright, cocoa-toned with balanced fruit, and richly floral.

Review_Description: Tropical fruit-toned. Mango, lychee, lime, dark chocolate, oak in aroma and cup. Very sweet structure with brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Fruity and chocolaty finish with aromatic wood notes.
Blind Assessment: Tropical fruit-toned. Mango, lychee, lime, dark chocolate, oak in aroma and cup. Very sweet structure with brisk acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Fruity and chocolaty finish with aromatic wood notes.
Notes: Produced by Marta Bayter and her sons, Shady and Elias, of Vergel Estate from the Red and Yellow Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method (whole fruit is fermented with limited oxygen before drying, still in the whole fruit). Oak & Bond is a specialty retail and wholesale coffee roaster based in Charlotte, North Carolina. The company’s name combines “oak,” a reference to its first coffee, a barrel-aged release, and “bond,” referring to the founders’ happy marriage. For more information, visit www.oakandbondcoffee.com.
Bottom Line: An exceptionally fruit-forward cup (think tropical melange) with undertones of dark chocolate throughout.

Review_Description: Gently sweet-tart, brightly confident. Dried raspberry, honeysuckle, cocoa nib, honey, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with fruity acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of cocoa nib with undertones and dried raspberry.
Blind Assessment: Gently sweet-tart, brightly confident. Dried raspberry, honeysuckle, cocoa nib, honey, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with fruity acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of cocoa nib with undertones and dried raspberry.
Notes: Produced by Cruz Jose Argüello Enriquez of Finca Santa Cruz entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Mute Roaster is a specialty coffee roaster based in Macao, China. Visit https://www.facebook.com/muteroaster for more information.
Bottom Line: A lovely natural-processed Mexico Geisha — berry- and cocoa-driven with pungent sandalwood undertones.

Coffee_Name: Costa Rica Canet Musician Beethoven Enzyme-Washed
Review_Description: Sweetly fruit-toned, crisply floral. Dried peach, honey, almond butter, magnolia, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with brisk acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The crisp finish leads with notes of dried peach, magnolia and almond.
Blind Assessment: Sweetly fruit-toned, crisply floral. Dried peach, honey, almond butter, magnolia, tangerine zest in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with brisk acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The crisp finish leads with notes of dried peach, magnolia and almond.
Notes: Produced by smallholding members of Asocafe Canet entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica, and processed by a variation of the honey method. Angeles Roastery is a Hong Kong-based coffee Roastery established in 2021. Visit www.angelesroastery.com for more information.
Bottom Line: An exceptionally sweet, innovatively processed Costa Rica cup with a floral throughline and notes of bittersweet citrus zest.

Review_Description: Crisply chocolaty and nut-toned, balanced. Baking chocolate, hazelnut butter, date, pink grapefruit zest, thyme in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with gently bright acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. Chocolaty, richly nutty finish.
Blind Assessment: Crisply chocolaty and nut-toned, balanced. Baking chocolate, hazelnut butter, date, pink grapefruit zest, thyme in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with gently bright acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. Chocolaty, richly nutty finish.
Notes: Produced by Ovidio Ramirez of Finca El Guachipilin from trees of the Bourbon, Pache, Caturra and Catuai varieties of Arabica, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Oak & Bond is a specialty retail and wholesale coffee roaster based in Charlotte, North Carolina. The company’s name combines “oak,” a reference to its first coffee, a barrel-aged release, and “bond,” referring to the founders’ happy marriage. For more information, visit www.oakandbondcoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A balanced, richly chocolaty, sweetly nutty washed-process Guatemala cup.

Review_Description: Richly floral-toned, exceptionally sweet. Distinct narcissus, cocoa nib, myrrh, blackberry, lemon thyme in aroma and cup. Complex bittersweet structure with floral acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Engaging, satisfying finish that carries over all aromas and flavors from the cup.
Blind Assessment: Richly floral-toned, exceptionally sweet. Distinct narcissus, cocoa nib, myrrh, blackberry, lemon thyme in aroma and cup. Complex bittersweet structure with floral acidity; very full, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Engaging, satisfying finish that carries over all aromas and flavors from the cup.
Notes: Produced by Wilton Benitez of Macarena Farm entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by an experimental method in which the coffee fruit is sterilized with ozonated water and ultraviolet light, then undergoes a natural anaerobic fermentation (whole fruit is fermented in hermetically sealed vessels) with the addition of yeast. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Bottom Line: A nuanced, complex experimentally processed Colombia Geisha cup with rich notes of spicy florals, ripe berries and sweet herb.

Review_Description: Richly aromatic, chocolaty, fruit-toned. Dark chocolate, dried mango, honeysuckle, wine barrel, marjoram in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with winey acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The long, lingering finish centers around notes of dark chocolate and spicy florals.
Coffee Origin: Trujillo, Valle del Cauca Department, Colombia
Blind Assessment: Richly aromatic, chocolaty, fruit-toned. Dark chocolate, dried mango, honeysuckle, wine barrel, marjoram in aroma and cup. Richly sweet structure with winey acidity; plush, syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The long, lingering finish centers around notes of dark chocolate and spicy florals.
Notes: Produced by Rigoberto Herrera of Granja La Esperanza entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (sun-dried in the whole fruit). Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was named the “2012 Micro-Roaster of the Year” by Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
Bottom Line: A trifecta of fruit, chocolate and flowers, both levitatingly sweet and structurally grounded.

Review_Description: High-toned, fruit-driven. Boysenberry, pear, cocoa nib, tangerine zest, pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy-bright acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of boysenberry and tangerine zest with undertones of pink peppercorn.
Blind Assessment: High-toned, fruit-driven. Boysenberry, pear, cocoa nib, tangerine zest, pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with juicy-bright acidity; crisp, velvety mouthfeel. The finish consolidates to notes of boysenberry and tangerine zest with undertones of pink peppercorn.
Notes: Produced at Mengesha Farm from selections of indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). With more than 10 years of roasting experience, Regent strives to deliver coffee with care and purpose. Visit regentcoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A fruit medley in a cup — think boysenberry and fresh pear — with a crisp cocoa throughline.

Coffee_Name: Colombia Tolima Finca El Mirador Washed Anaerobic
Review_Description: Delicately fruit-toned. Guava, ginger blossom, cocoa nib, cedar, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish, supported by notes of cedar and agave.
Blind Assessment: Delicately fruit-toned. Guava, ginger blossom, cocoa nib, cedar, agave syrup in aroma and cup. Sweet-toned structure with juicy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned finish, supported by notes of cedar and agave.
Notes: Produced by Victor Gutiérrez of Finca Mirador entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica. Processed by the anaerobic washed method, in which the fermentation step occurs in a hermetically sealed vessel before the beans are washed and dried. With more than 10 years of roasting experience, Regent strives to deliver coffee with care and purpose. Visit regentcoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: An appealing washed anaerobic cup: deep-toned, nuanced, richly sweet.

Review_Description: Richly fruit-forward, floral-toned. Lychee, tea rose, dark chocolate, orange zest, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with bright acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Cedar notes support the crisply fruit-toned finish.
Blind Assessment: Richly fruit-forward, floral-toned. Lychee, tea rose, dark chocolate, orange zest, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Savory-leaning structure with bright acidity; full, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Cedar notes support the crisply fruit-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by Jamison Savage of Finca Debra entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in an oxygen-free environment before drying. This particular fermentation, described as “extended,” was 100 hours in duration. Theory Coffee Roasters is a specialty roaster and coffee shop based in Redding, California. Visit www.theorycoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A floral- and fruit-driven anaerobic natural Panama Geisha cup with leading notes of dark chocolate and rich aromatic wood.

Review_Description: High-toned, richly bittersweet. Pomelo, raspberry, cocoa nib, limoncello, a hint of sage in aroma and cup. Bittersweet structure with juicy acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. The resonant finish leads with notes of pomelo and sage, rounding to cocoa nib in the long.
Blind Assessment: High-toned, richly bittersweet. Pomelo, raspberry, cocoa nib, limoncello, a hint of sage in aroma and cup. Bittersweet structure with juicy acidity; crisp, syrupy mouthfeel. The resonant finish leads with notes of pomelo and sage, rounding to cocoa nib in the long.
Notes: Produced by Jamison Savage of Finca Debra entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by an experimental method described as “cascara-infused washed carbonic maceration,” in which the coffee fruit is first pulped, leaving some flesh on the seed, then fermented in CO2-infused tanks along with cascara (the skin and pulp of the coffee fruit). Theory Coffee Roasters is a specialty roaster and coffee shop based in Redding, California. Visit www.theorycoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A complex, multi-layered experimentally processed Geisha cup with focused fruit supported by crisp cocoa notes.

Review_Description: Crisply sweet-tart. Apricot, cocoa nib, agave syrup, narcissus, almond in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. Sweetly nut-toned finish with undertones of narcissus.
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-tart. Apricot, cocoa nib, agave syrup, narcissus, almond in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart structure with brisk acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. Sweetly nut-toned finish with undertones of narcissus.
Notes: Produced by Jamison Savage of Finca Debra entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica and processed by a variation on the carbonic maceration method, which involves fermenting whole coffee fruit inside a sealed container that has been flushed with CO2. The beans are then pulped and finished by the conventional washed method. Theory Coffee Roasters is a specialty roaster and coffee shop based in Redding, California. Visit www.theorycoffee.com for more information.
Bottom Line: A balanced, richly sweet Panama Geisha cup, processed by a variation on the carbonic maceration method and leading with notes of stone fruit and sweet almond.

Review_Description: High-toned, juicy-sweet. Mango, cocoa nib, magnolia, lemongrass, pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with bright, balanced acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Flavor-laden finish, long and lingering, centered around notes of mango and cocoa nib.
Blind Assessment: High-toned, juicy-sweet. Mango, cocoa nib, magnolia, lemongrass, pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Sweet-tart structure with bright, balanced acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Flavor-laden finish, long and lingering, centered around notes of mango and cocoa nib.
Notes: Produced by smallholding farmers from trees of the 74110, 74112 and other local varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the traditional washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) at Daye Bensa Washing Station. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Bottom Line: An invitingly elegant washed Ethiopia cup, deftly balancing fruit, floral and cocoa tones — buoyantly juicy and complete.

Review_Description: Richly spice-toned, floral-driven. Bergamot, lilac, cocoa nib, blackberry, wild honey in aroma and cup. Complex, bittersweet structure with juicy, balanced acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. The long, flavor-saturated finish carries over all the nuance of the cup.
Blind Assessment: Richly spice-toned, floral-driven. Bergamot, lilac, cocoa nib, blackberry, wild honey in aroma and cup. Complex, bittersweet structure with juicy, balanced acidity; plush, creamy mouthfeel. The long, flavor-saturated finish carries over all the nuance of the cup.
Notes: Produced by small-holding farmers largely from trees of selections of indigenous landrace varieties of Arabica long grown in the region, and processed by the anaerobic natural method, in which the whole fruit is fermented in an oxygen-free environment before drying. Paradise prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Bottom Line: A lyrically composed Ethiopia anaerobic cup with judicious fruit, spice-toned florals and richly vibrant cocoa and honey impulses.

Review_Description: High-toned, crisply sweet-tart. Lemongrass, cocoa nib, tea rose, magnolia, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy, sparkling acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The resonant finish leads with notes of lemongrass and cocoa nib, with undertones of magnolia.
Blind Assessment: High-toned, crisply sweet-tart. Lemongrass, cocoa nib, tea rose, magnolia, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Brightly sweet structure with juicy, sparkling acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. The resonant finish leads with notes of lemongrass and cocoa nib, with undertones of magnolia.
Notes: Produced by Gibran Leonardo Cervantes Covarrubias of Cafetal El Equimite entirely of the Geisha variety of Arabica, and processed by the natural method (dried in the whole fruit). Certified USDA Organic. SkyTop Coffee is a USDA certified-organic specialty coffee roaster based in Manlius, New York. For more information, visit skytopcoffee.com.
Bottom Line: A particularly fine Mexico Geisha: elegantly spice-toned, richly floral, deeply sweet and complex.

Coffee_Name: Costa Rica Las Lajas Red Honey
Review_Description: Crisply sweet-tart, richly fruit-toned Costa Rica coffee produced by Oscar and Francisca Chacon and roasted by Durango Coffee in Durango, Colorado.
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela, Alajuela Province, Costa Rica
Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-tart, richly fruit-toned Costa Rica coffee produced by Oscar and Francisca Chacon and roasted by Durango Coffee in Durango, Colorado.
Notes: Produced by Oscar and Francisca Chacon from trees of the Caturra and Catuai varieties of Arabica; certified organically grown. Processed by the red honey method, meaning that most of the fruit flesh (“honey”) was allowed to adhere to the beans during drying. Located in southwestern Colorado, Durango Coffee lays claim to a rich coffee history that dates to 1986. Its motto is “Tough Town, Great Coffee.” Visit www.durangocoffee.com or call 800-748-2275 for more information.
Bottom Line: This honey-processed Costa Rica shows a berry throughline with undertones of rich florals and a resiny, amber-like note that contributes depth and complexity.

Review_Description: Very sweet, orangey and chocolate-toned. Ripe mandarin orange, dark chocolate, hazelnut, freesia-like flowers, cedar in aroma and cup. Sweet structure with tart, citrusy acidity; crisp, satiny mouthfeel. Sweetly citrusy, wood-framed finish with undertones of dark chocolate.
